Data Distribution Valuation

Xinyi Xu
Department of Computer Science
National University of Singapore
xinyi.xu@u.nus.edu
Majority of work done when visiting CMU. â€ƒâ€ƒ Shuaiqi Wang
Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
Carnegie Mellon University
shuaiqiw@andrew.cmu.edu
â€ƒâ€ƒ Chuan-Sheng Foo
Institute for Infocomm Research
Agency for Science, Technology and Research
foo_chuan_sheng@i2r.a-star.edu.sg â€ƒâ€ƒ Bryan Kian Hsiang Low
Department of Computer Science
National University of Singapore
lowkh@comp.nus.edu.sg
â€ƒâ€ƒ Giulia Fanti
Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
Carnegie Mellon University
gfanti@andrew.cmu.edu
Abstract

Data valuation is a class of techniques for quantitatively assessing the value of data for applications like pricing in data marketplaces. Existing data valuation methods define a value for a discrete dataset. However, in many use cases, users are interested in not only the value of the dataset, but that of the distribution from which the dataset was sampled. For example, consider a buyer trying to evaluate whether to purchase data from different vendors. The buyer may observe (and compare) only a small preview sample from each vendor, to decide which vendorâ€™s data distribution is most useful to the buyer and purchase. The core question is how should we compare the values of data distributions from their samples? Under a Huber characterization of the data heterogeneity across vendors, we propose a maximum mean discrepancy (MMD)-based valuation method which enables theoretically principled and actionable policies for comparing data distributions from samples. We empirically demonstrate that our method is sample-efficient and effective in identifying valuable data distributions against several existing baselines, on multiple real-world datasets (e.g., network intrusion detection, credit card fraud detection) and downstream applications (classification, regression).

1 Introduction

Data valuation is a widely-studied practice of quantifying the value of data [57]. Today, data valuation methods define a value for a discrete dataset Dğ·Ditalic_D, i.e., a fixed set of samples [24, 32]. However, many emerging use cases require a data user to evaluate the quality of not just a dataset, but the distribution from which the data was sampled. For example, data vendors in markets like Datarade and Snowflake, financial data streams [46, 52], information security data [22]) offer a preview in the form of a sample dataset to prospective buyers [4, 11]. Similarly, enterprises selling access to generative models may offer a limited preview of the output distributions to prospective buyers [53]. Buyers use these sample datasets to decide whether to pay for a full dataset or data streamâ€”i.e., access to the data distribution. Concretely, the buyers would compare between different data distributions (via their respective sample datasets) to determine and select the more valuable one.

In such applications, existing dataset valuation metrics are missing two components: (1) They do not formalize the value of the underlying sampling distribution, (2) nor do they provide a theoretically principled and actionable policy for comparing different sampling distributions based on the sample datasets. For example, most existing data valuation techniques are designed only to value a datasetÂ [57]. To our knowledge, there are no methods designed to value an underlying distribution.

To model this problem, we consider a data buyer who wishes to evaluate nğ‘›nitalic_n data vendors, each with their own dataset Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT drawn i.i.d.Â from distribution Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ]. The vendorsâ€™ distributions are heterogeneous, i.e., the Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s can differ across vendors. Such distributional heterogeneity can arise from natural variations in data [12] or adversarial data corruption [27, 64]. The buyerâ€™s goal is to select the vendor whose data distribution is closest in some sense (to be defined) to a reference distribution Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is fixed but unknown. Our goal is to provide both a precise definition for the value of the vendor distribution Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respect to Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as well as a corresponding valuation for the sample dataset Diâˆ¼Pisimilar-tosubscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–D_{i}\sim P_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In particular, we want precise conditions under which, given two datasets Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Djsubscriptğ·ğ‘—D_{j}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT drawn from distributions Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Pjsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘—P_{j}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively, we can conclude that Pi>Pj+ÎµÎ¥subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘—subscriptğœ€Î¥P_{i}>P_{j}+\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some user-specified ÎµÎ¥>0subscriptğœ€Î¥0\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}>0italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 with fixed probability. While this problem is straightforward when different vendors have the same underlying distribution, the main challenge is accounting for the heterogeneity in the data.

We thus identify three technical and modeling challenges: (i) What is a suitable heterogeneity model that captures realistic data patterns, while also admitting theoretical analysis? (ii) How should one define the value of a distribution under a given heterogeneity model? (iii) Many existing data valuation methods use a reference Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, either explicitlyÂ [24, 33, 55] or implicitlyÂ [1, 14]. However, there are practical difficulties: (1) different data vendors may disagree on the choice of referenceÂ [69], (2) such a reference may not be available a prioriÂ [14, 56], or (3) dishonest vendors may try to overfit to the referenceÂ [2]. To address this, some works consider alternatives (to Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) based on the vendorsâ€™ distributions Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s such as their unionÂ [59] or a certain combinationÂ [65], but without theoretical analysis or justifications for their specific choices. So what is a practical alternative, and how can we theoretically justify it?

To address these challenges, we make three key choices.

(a) Heterogeneity model. We assume that each vendorâ€™s data distribution Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Huber model [30], which is a mixture model of the unknown distribution Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and an arbitrary outlier distribution Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. While the Huber model does not capture all kinds of statistical heterogeneity, mixture models both are a reasonable model for data heterogeneity in practice [9, 54] and have deeper roots in robust statistics [20, 40]. More importantly, the Huber model enables a direct and precise characterization of the effect of heterogeneity on the value of data (under our design choices (b) and (c) below), which has not been considered in prior worksÂ [1, 14, 65].

(b) Value of a sampling distribution. We use the negative maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) [26] between a reference distribution Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P as the value of the sampling distribution Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. Then, we leverage a (uniformly converging) MMD estimator [26] to derive actionable policies for comparing sampling distributions with theoretical guarantees. In other words, a buyer can compare (the values of) sampling distributions Pi,Piâ€²subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘–â€²P_{i},P_{i^{\prime}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (from vendors i,iâ€²ğ‘–superscriptğ‘–â€²i,i^{\prime}italic_i , italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) based on the respective samples Di,Diâ€²subscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ·superscriptğ‘–â€²D_{i},D_{i^{\prime}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to determine which is more valuable, and by how much.

(c) Choice of reference data distribution and dataset. Unlike in prior works (e.g., [24, 66]), we do not specify a reference distribution outright. Instead, we consider a class of convex mixtures of vendor distributions as the reference. We first derive error guarantees and an actionable comparison policy for using general convex mixture of the vendorsâ€™ distributions as the reference. We then propose to use the special case of a uniform mixture, justified by a game-theoretic argument, stating that the uniform strategy is worst-case optimal in a two-player zero-sum game.

These design choices are not isolated answers to each technical challenge, but collectively address these challenges (e.g., the analytic properties of both Huber and MMD are needed to compare distributions effectively). Our specific contributions are summarized as follows:

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bulletâˆ™

    We formulate the problem of data distribution valuation in data markets and study an MMD-based method for data distribution valuation. Under a Huber model of data heterogeneity, we show that this data valuation metric admits actionable, theoretically-grounded policies for comparing sampling distributions from samples.

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bulletâˆ™

    We derive an error guarantee (2) and comparison policy (TheoremÂ 1) for a general convex mixture PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as a reference (in place of Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), thus relaxing the common assumption of knowing Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We then identify the uniform mixture as a game-theoretic special case for PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bulletâˆ™

    We demonstrate on real-world classification (e.g., network intrusion detection) and regression (e.g., income prediction) tasks that our method is sample-efficient, and effective in identifying the most valuable sampling distributions against existing baselines. For example, on classification tasks, we observed that an MMD-based valuation method outperformed four leading valuation metrics on 3 out of 4 classification settings (TableÂ 2).

2 Related Work

Existing dataset valuation methods fall roughly in 2222 categories: those that assume a given reference dataset, and those that do not. We defer additional discussion to App.Â B due to space constraints.

With a given reference. Several existing methods require a given reference in the form of a validation set (e.g., [24, 39]) or a baseline dataset [2]. Data ShapleyÂ [24], Beta ShapleyÂ [39] and Data BanzhafÂ [43, 62] utilize the validation accuracy of a trained model as the value of the training data. Class-wise ShapleyÂ [55] evaluates the effects of a dataset on the in-class and out-of-class validation accuracies. Both LAVAÂ [33] and DAVINZÂ [66] use a proxy for the validation performance of the training data as their value, instead of the actual validation performance, to be independent of the choice of downstream task ML model [33] or to remove the need for model training [66]. Differently, [2] assume that the buyer provides a baseline dataset as the reference to calculate a relevance score used to evaluate the vendorâ€™s data. Therefore, these methods cannot be applied without such a given reference, which can be difficult to obtain in practice [14, 56]. In contrast, our method can be applied without a given reference, by carefully constructing a reference (Sec.Â 4.2).

Without a given reference. To relax the assumption of a given reference, [14, 59, 65] construct a reference from the data from all vendors. While the settings of [14, 59, 65] can include heterogeneity in the vendorsâ€™ data, they do not explicitly formalize it and thus cannot precisely analyze its effects on data valuation. In contrast, our method, via the careful design choices of the Huber model (for heterogeneity) and MMD (for valuation), uniquely offers a precise analysis on the effect of heterogeneity on the value of data (Eq.Â 2). Furthermore, these methods did not provide theoretical guarantees on the error arising from using their constructed reference in place of the ground truth (i.e., Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). In contrast, by exploiting 1 in the setting of multiple vendors and the MMD-based valuation (Eq.Â 1), we provide such theoretical guarantees (e.g., 2). In a different approach to relax the assumption of a given reference, [56, 69] remove the dependence on a reference; as a result they can produce counter-intuitive data values under heterogeneous data (experiments in Sec.Â 5). The closest related work to ours is [59], which adopts the MMD2 as a valuation metric, primarily for computational reasons. However, this work does not consider data distribution valuation, nor does it describe how to compare (the values of) distributions, let alone with theoretical guarantees. This comparison (with MMD2) is expanded in Sec.Â B.2.

TableÂ 1 provides a comparison between our choice (MMD) and three others: the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergenceÂ [1, 65], the Wasserstein distanceÂ (WD)Â [33], and squared MMD (MMD2)Â [59].

3 Model, Problem Statement and MMD

We consider a set of data vendors iâˆˆNâ‰”{1,â€¦,n}ğ‘–ğ‘â‰”1â€¦ğ‘›i\in N\coloneqq\{1,\ldots,n\}italic_i âˆˆ italic_N â‰” { 1 , â€¦ , italic_n }, each with a sample dataset Diâ‰”{zi,1,â€¦,zi,mi}â‰”subscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ‘§ğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘§ğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘–D_{i}\coloneqq\{z_{i,1},\ldots,z_{i,m_{i}}\}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” { italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of size misubscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where zi,jsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘—z_{i,j}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is sampled i.i.d.Â from the distribution Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [10]. Slightly abusing notations, we write Diâˆ¼Pisimilar-tosubscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–D_{i}\sim P_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We assume the existence of an unknown ground truth distribution Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, called the test distribution [24, 32], true data distribution [1] or the task distributionÂ [2].

Huber model. We assume that each sampling distribution Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follows a Huber model [30], defined as follows: Pi=(1âˆ’Îµi)â¢Pâˆ—+Îµiâ¢Qisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–1subscriptğœ€ğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ€ğ‘–subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–P_{i}=(1-\varepsilon_{i})P^{*}+\varepsilon_{i}Q_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where Îµiâˆˆ[0,1)subscriptğœ€ğ‘–01\varepsilon_{i}\in[0,1)italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ) and Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a distribution that captures the heterogeneity of vendor iğ‘–iitalic_i [27]. For notational simplicity, we omit the subscript iğ‘–iitalic_i and write D,Pğ·ğ‘ƒD,Pitalic_D , italic_P instead of Di,Pisubscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–D_{i},P_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, when it is clear. We adopt the Huber model because (i) it is sufficiently general to model various sources of heterogeneity [12, 13]; (ii) Huber models are â€œclosedâ€ under mixtures (i.e., a mixture of Hubers is a Huber model), so we can define a mixture over data vendorsâ€™ distributions:

Observation 1.

For a mixture weight Ï‰âˆˆâ–³â¢(nâˆ’1)ğœ”â–³ğ‘›1\omega\in\triangle(n-1)italic_Ï‰ âˆˆ â–³ ( italic_n - 1 ),111Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ is an nğ‘›nitalic_n-dimensional probability vector in the nâˆ’1ğ‘›1n-1italic_n - 1 simplex. define the mixture PÏ‰â‰”âˆ‘iâˆˆNÏ‰iâ¢Pi.â‰”subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”subscriptğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğœ”ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{\omega}\coloneqq\sum_{i\in N}\omega_{i}P_{i}.italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Then, PÏ‰=(1âˆ’ÎµÏ‰)â¢Pâˆ—+ÎµÏ‰â¢QÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”1subscriptğœ€ğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ€ğœ”subscriptğ‘„ğœ”P_{\omega}=(1-\varepsilon_{\omega})P^{*}+\varepsilon_{\omega}Q_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where ÎµÏ‰=âˆ‘iâˆˆNÏ‰iâ¢Îµisubscriptğœ€ğœ”subscriptğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğœ”ğ‘–subscriptğœ€ğ‘–\varepsilon_{\omega}=\sum_{i\in N}\omega_{i}\varepsilon_{i}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and QÏ‰=(1/ÎµÏ‰)â¢âˆ‘iâˆˆN(Ï‰iâ¢Îµiâ¢Qi).subscriptğ‘„ğœ”1subscriptğœ€ğœ”subscriptğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğœ”ğ‘–subscriptğœ€ğ‘–subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{\omega}=(1/\varepsilon_{\omega})\sum_{i\in N}(\omega_{i}\varepsilon_{i}Q_{i% })\ .italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 / italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

The mixture distribution PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (of individual Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s) is a Huber model, which is used in the theoretical results in Sec.Â 4.2. Define DÏ‰subscriptğ·ğœ”D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the sample dataset by randomly sampling from each Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT w.p.Â Ï‰isubscriptğœ”ğ‘–\omega_{i}italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so effectively DÏ‰âˆ¼PÏ‰similar-tosubscriptğ·ğœ”subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”D_{\omega}\sim P_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In particular, if Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ is uniform (i.e., âˆ€i,Ï‰i=1/nfor-allğ‘–subscriptğœ”ğ‘–1ğ‘›\forall i,\omega_{i}=1/nâˆ€ italic_i , italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 / italic_n), we denote the corresponding PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, DÏ‰subscriptğ·ğœ”D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as DUsubscriptğ·UD_{\text{U}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ÎµÏ‰subscriptğœ€ğœ”\varepsilon_{\omega}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as ÎµUsubscriptğœ€U\varepsilon_{\text{U}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and QÏ‰subscriptğ‘„ğœ”Q_{\omega}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as QU.subscriptğ‘„UQ_{\text{U}}.italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . We further expand our considerations of the Huber model to characterize data heterogeneity w.r.t.Â existing works in Sec.Â B.3. Later, we also empirically investigate non-Huber settings where our method (in Sec.Â 4) remains effective (Sec.Â D.3.4).

Problem statement. Given two datasets Dâˆ¼Psimilar-toğ·ğ‘ƒD\sim Pitalic_D âˆ¼ italic_P and Dâ€²âˆ¼Pâ€²similar-tosuperscriptğ·â€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²D^{\prime}\sim P^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we seek a distribution valuation function Î¥â¢(â‹…)Î¥â‹…\Upsilon(\cdot)roman_Î¥ ( â‹… ) and a dataset valuation function Î½â¢(â‹…)ğœˆâ‹…\nu(\cdot)italic_Î½ ( â‹… ) which enable a set of conditions under which to conclude that Î¥â¢(P)>Î¥â¢(Pâ€²)Î¥ğ‘ƒÎ¥superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\Upsilon(P)>\Upsilon(P^{\prime})roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) > roman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), given only Î½â¢(D)ğœˆğ·\nu(D)italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) and Î½â¢(Dâ€²)ğœˆsuperscriptğ·â€²\nu(D^{\prime})italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Moreover, we seek a practical implementation of Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ that does not require access to the ground truth distribution Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as reference or any prior knowledge about the vendors (except each Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is Huber).

Existing methods cannot be easily applied to solve this problem. First, existing methods (e.g., [24, 32] do not define Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥; hence, they cannot analyze the conditions under which Î¥â¢(P)>Î¥â¢(Pâ€²)Î¥ğ‘ƒÎ¥superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\Upsilon(P)>\Upsilon(P^{\prime})roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) > roman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). In App.Â C, we elaborate why a dataset valuation Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½ cannot be easily extended to a data distribution valuation Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ and also highlight the theoretical appeal of directly considering Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ instead. Additionally, methods that explicitly require access to the reference distribution via Dâˆ—âˆ¼Pâˆ—similar-tosuperscriptğ·superscriptğ‘ƒD^{*}\sim P^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (e.g., [39, 55, 66]) cannot be applied here. For other methods, additional non-trivial assumptions (e.g., [14, Assumption 3.2], [65, Assumption 3.1]) are required; we elaborate on these in Sec.Â B.1.

3.1 Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD)

The MMD is an integral probability metric proposed to test if two distributions are the same.

Definition 1 (MMD, [26, DefinitionÂ 2]).

For a class â„±â„±\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F of functions fğ‘“fitalic_f in the unit ball of the reproducing kernel Hilbert space associated with a kernel function kğ‘˜kitalic_k, the MMD, which is symmetric, between two distributions P,Pâ€²ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P,P^{\prime}italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is dâ¢(P,Pâ€²;â„±)â‰”supfâˆˆâ„±ğ”¼Xâˆ¼Pâ¢fâ¢(X)âˆ’ğ”¼Wâˆ¼Pâ€²â¢fâ¢(W).â‰”ğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²â„±subscriptsupremumğ‘“â„±subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘‹ğ‘ƒğ‘“ğ‘‹subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²ğ‘“ğ‘Šd(P,P^{\prime};\mathcal{F})\coloneqq\sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}}\mathbb{E}_{X\sim P}% f(X)-\mathbb{E}_{W\sim P^{\prime}}f(W)\ .italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_F ) â‰” roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X âˆ¼ italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_X ) - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_W ) .

The MMD has a (biased) estimator for Dâˆ¼Psimilar-toğ·ğ‘ƒD\sim Pitalic_D âˆ¼ italic_P and Dâ€²âˆ¼Pâ€²similar-tosuperscriptğ·â€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²D^{\prime}\sim P^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and |D|=m,|Dâ€²|=mâ€²formulae-sequenceğ·ğ‘šsuperscriptğ·â€²superscriptğ‘šâ€²|D|=m,|D^{\prime}|=m^{\prime}| italic_D | = italic_m , | italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | = italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [26, Eq.Â (5)]: d^â¢(D,Dâ€²)â‰”[1m2â¢âˆ‘x,xâ€²âˆˆDkâ¢(x,xâ€²)âˆ’2mâ¢mâ€²â¢âˆ‘(x,w)âˆˆDÃ—Dâ€²kâ¢(x,w)+1mâ€²â£2â¢âˆ‘w,wâ€²âˆˆDâ€²kâ¢(w,wâ€²)]0.5.â‰”^ğ‘‘ğ·superscriptğ·â€²superscriptdelimited-[]1superscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ·ğ‘˜ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²2ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘šâ€²subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¤ğ·superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘˜ğ‘¥ğ‘¤1superscriptğ‘šâ€²2subscriptğ‘¤superscriptğ‘¤â€²superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘˜ğ‘¤superscriptğ‘¤â€²0.5\hat{d}(D,D^{\prime})\coloneqq\boldsymbol{[}\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{x,x^{\prime}% \in D}k(x,x^{\prime})-\frac{2}{mm^{\prime}}\sum_{(x,w)\in D\times D^{\prime}}k% (x,w)+\frac{1}{m^{\prime 2}}\sum_{w,w^{\prime}\in D^{\prime}}k(w,w^{\prime})% \boldsymbol{]}^{0.5}\ .over^ start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰” bold_[ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ( italic_x , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_w ) âˆˆ italic_D Ã— italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ( italic_x , italic_w ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w , italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ( italic_w , italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) bold_] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0.5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Importantly, this estimator satisfies uniform convergence (LemmaÂ 1), which is used in our theoretical results (e.g., 1). We denote with Kğ¾Kitalic_K an upper bound on the kernel kğ‘˜kitalic_k: âˆ€x,xâ€²for-allğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²\forall x,x^{\prime}âˆ€ italic_x , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, kâ¢(x,xâ€²)â‰¤Kğ‘˜ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ¾k(x,x^{\prime})\leq Kitalic_k ( italic_x , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_K. As â„±â„±\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F is associated with kğ‘˜kitalic_k and kept constant throughout, its notational dependence is suppressed.

4 MMD-based Data Distribution Valuation

A distribution valuation function should intuitively reward distributions Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P that are â€œcloser" to the reference distribution Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; accordingly, it should assign greater reward to datasets Dâˆ¼Psimilar-toğ·ğ‘ƒD\sim Pitalic_D âˆ¼ italic_P that are drawn from distributions that are closer to Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We study the following data distribution valuation:

Î¥â¢(P)â‰”âˆ’dâ¢(P,Pâˆ—),Î½â¢(D)â‰”âˆ’d^â¢(D,Dâˆ—).formulae-sequenceâ‰”Î¥ğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ‰”ğœˆğ·^ğ‘‘ğ·superscriptğ·\Upsilon(P)\coloneqq-d(P,P^{*})\ ,\quad\nu(D)\coloneqq-\hat{d}(D,D^{*})\ .roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) â‰” - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) â‰” - over^ start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (1)

To interpret, the value Î¥â¢(P)Î¥ğ‘ƒ\Upsilon(P)roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) of a vendorâ€™s sampling distribution Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P is defined as the negated MMD between Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, while the value Î½â¢(D)ğœˆğ·\nu(D)italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) of its sample dataset Dğ·Ditalic_D is defined as the negated MMD estimate between Dğ·Ditalic_D and the reference dataset Dâˆ—superscriptğ·D^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

On the choice of MMD. We summarize a comparison with three alternatives (i.e., KL-divergence (KL), Wasserstein Distance (WD), and MMD2) in TableÂ 1 to highlight the suitability of MMD for data distribution valuation. Despite its wide adoption, KL is difficult to estimate, and the available estimator only has asymptotic convergence guaranteesÂ [63] (rather than a finite-sample result), which can be arbitrarily slow. Its implementation also suffers from the curse of dimensionalityÂ [58, 63]. In addition, KL does not satisfy the triangle inequality, which our proof technique uses in 2. WD, also known as the optimal transport (OT) distance [34], suffers from the curse of dimensionality, as seen in the complexity resultsÂ [23] in TableÂ 1, and is more computationally costly to evaluate than MMD. MMD2, though shares similar complexity results to MMD, does not satisfy desirable analytic properties, such as the triangle inequality or the property with Huber model. This comparison over divergences is expanded in Sec.Â B.2.

MMD is both practically and theoretically appealing for data distribution valuation. Practically, MMD has lower sample and computational complexities in the dimension of the data, which is important because the real-world datasets can be complex and have a high dimension. Specifically, we leverage the uniform convergence (with sample complexity as in TableÂ 1) of an MMD estimator to derive an actionable policy for comparing two distributions (i.e., 1, TheoremÂ 1). Theoretically, MMD satisfies the triangle inequality, making it amenable to theoretical analysis, such as the derivation of our error guarantee (i.e., 2). Moreover, MMD pairs well with the Huber model in providing a precise characterization of the effect of heterogeneity on the value of data. In contrast, existing valuation works have not established a formal analysis on the heterogeneity (w.r.t.Â a specific choice for heterogeneity) on the value of data, elaborated in Sec.Â B.3.

Effect of heterogeneity on data valuation. Intuitively, the quality of a Huber distribution Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P depends on both the size of the outlier component Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ and the statistical difference dâ¢(Pâˆ—,Q)ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘„d(P^{*},Q)italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q ) between Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q and Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A larger Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ and/or a larger dâ¢(Pâˆ—,Q)ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘„d(P^{*},Q)italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q ) decreases the value Î¥â¢(P)Î¥ğ‘ƒ\Upsilon(P)roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ). Our choice of MMD makes this intuition precise and interpretable: By LemmaÂ 2, for P=(1âˆ’Îµ)â¢Pâˆ—+Îµâ¢Qğ‘ƒ1ğœ€superscriptğ‘ƒğœ€ğ‘„P=(1-\varepsilon)P^{*}+\varepsilon Qitalic_P = ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Îµ italic_Q,

Î¥â¢(P)=âˆ’Îµâ¢dâ¢(Pâˆ—,Q).Î¥ğ‘ƒğœ€ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘„\Upsilon(P)=-\varepsilon d(P^{*},Q)\ .roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) = - italic_Îµ italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q ) . (2)

Eq.Â 2 shows that for a fixed Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ, Pğ‘ƒPitalic_Pâ€™s value decreases linearly w.r.t.Â dâ¢(Pâˆ—,Q)ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘„d(P^{*},Q)italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q ); similarly, for a fixed dâ¢(Pâˆ—,Q)ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘„d(P^{*},Q)italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q ), Pğ‘ƒPitalic_Pâ€™s value decreases linearly w.r.t.Â Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ. Importantly, Eq.Â 2 enables subsequent results and a theoretically justified choice for the reference (e.g., LemmaÂ 4 to derive TheoremÂ 1 in Sec.Â 4.2).

4.1 Data Valuation with a Ground Truth Reference

With Eq.Â 1, we return to the problem statement described above: given two datasets Dâˆ¼Psimilar-toğ·ğ‘ƒD\sim Pitalic_D âˆ¼ italic_P and Dâ€²âˆ¼Pâ€²similar-tosuperscriptğ·â€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²D^{\prime}\sim P^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, under what conditions can we conclude that Î¥â¢(P)>Î¥â¢(Pâ€²)Î¥ğ‘ƒÎ¥superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\Upsilon(P)>\Upsilon(P^{\prime})roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) > roman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )? We first assume access to a reference dataset Dâˆ—âˆ¼Pâˆ—similar-tosuperscriptğ·superscriptğ‘ƒD^{*}\sim P^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We then relax this assumption in Sec.Â 4.2.

Proposition 1.

Given datasets Dâˆ¼Psimilar-toğ·ğ‘ƒD\sim Pitalic_D âˆ¼ italic_P and Dâ€²âˆ¼Pâ€²similar-tosuperscriptğ·â€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²D^{\prime}\sim P^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, let mâ‰”|D|â‰”ğ‘šğ·m\coloneqq|D|italic_m â‰” | italic_D | and mâ€²â‰”|Dâ€²|â‰”superscriptğ‘šâ€²superscriptğ·â€²m^{\prime}\coloneqq|D^{\prime}|italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” | italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT |. Let Dâˆ—âˆ¼Pâˆ—similar-tosuperscriptğ·superscriptğ‘ƒD^{*}\sim P^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and mâˆ—â‰”|Dâˆ—|â‰”superscriptğ‘šsuperscriptğ·m^{*}\coloneqq|D^{*}|italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” | italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | be its size. For some bias requirement Îµbiasâ‰¥0subscriptğœ€bias0\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}\geq 0italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 and a required decision margin ÎµÎ¥â‰¥0subscriptğœ€Î¥0\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}\geq 0italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0. If Î½â¢(D)>Î½â¢(Dâ€²)+Î”Î¥,Î½ğœˆğ·ğœˆsuperscriptğ·â€²subscriptÎ”Î¥ğœˆ\nu(D)>\nu(D^{\prime})+\Delta_{\Upsilon,\nu}italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) > italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ , italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where the criterion margin Î”Î¥,Î½â‰”ÎµÎ¥+2â¢[Îµbias+K/m+K/mâ€²+2â¢K/mâˆ—]â‰”subscriptÎ”Î¥ğœˆsubscriptğœ€Î¥2delimited-[]subscriptğœ€biasğ¾ğ‘šğ¾superscriptğ‘šâ€²2ğ¾superscriptğ‘š\Delta_{\Upsilon,\nu}\coloneqq\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}+2[\varepsilon_{\text{bias% }}+\sqrt{K/m}+\sqrt{K/m^{\prime}}+2\sqrt{K/m^{*}}]roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ , italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 [ italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + square-root start_ARG italic_K / italic_m end_ARG + square-root start_ARG italic_K / italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + 2 square-root start_ARG italic_K / italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ]. Let Î´â‰”2â¢expâ¡(âˆ’Îµbias2â¢mÂ¯â¢mâˆ—2â¢Kâ¢(mÂ¯+mâˆ—))â‰”ğ›¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ€bias2Â¯ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘š2ğ¾Â¯ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘š\delta\coloneqq 2\exp(\frac{-\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}^{2}\overline{m}m^{*}}{2% K(\overline{m}+m^{*})})italic_Î´ â‰” 2 roman_exp ( divide start_ARG - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_m end_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_m end_ARG + italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) where mÂ¯=maxâ¡{m,mâ€²}Â¯ğ‘šğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘šâ€²\overline{m}=\max\{m,m^{\prime}\}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_m end_ARG = roman_max { italic_m , italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }. Then, Î¥â¢(P)>Î¥â¢(Pâ€²)+ÎµÎ¥Î¥ğ‘ƒÎ¥superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²subscriptğœ€Î¥\Upsilon(P)>\Upsilon(P^{\prime})+\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) > roman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with probability at least (1âˆ’2â¢Î´)12ğ›¿(1-2\delta)( 1 - 2 italic_Î´ ).

(Proof in App.Â A) 1 describes the criterion margin Î”Î¥,Î½subscriptÎ”Î¥ğœˆ\Delta_{\Upsilon,\nu}roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ , italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that if Î½â¢(D)âˆ’Î½â¢(Dâ€²)>Î”Î¥,Î½ğœˆğ·ğœˆsuperscriptğ·â€²subscriptÎ”Î¥ğœˆ\nu(D)-\nu(D^{\prime})>\Delta_{\Upsilon,\nu}italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) - italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) > roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ , italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€”i.e., the criterion is metâ€”we can draw the conclusion that Î¥â¢(P)>Î¥â¢(Pâ€²)+ÎµÎ¥Î¥ğ‘ƒÎ¥superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²subscriptğœ€Î¥\Upsilon(P)>\Upsilon(P^{\prime})+\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) > roman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at a confidence level of 1âˆ’2â¢Î´12ğ›¿1-2\delta1 - 2 italic_Î´. Hence, a smaller Î”Î¥,Î½subscriptÎ”Î¥ğœˆ\Delta_{\Upsilon,\nu}roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ , italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT corresponds to an â€œeasierâ€ criterion to satisfy. The expression Î”Î¥,Î½=ğ’ªâ¢(ÎµÎ¥+Îµbias+1/mÂ¯)subscriptÎ”Î¥ğœˆğ’ªsubscriptğœ€Î¥subscriptğœ€bias1Â¯ğ‘š\Delta_{\Upsilon,\nu}=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}+\varepsilon_{\text{% bias}}+1/\sqrt{\underline{m}})roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ , italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_O ( italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 / square-root start_ARG underÂ¯ start_ARG italic_m end_ARG end_ARG ) where mÂ¯â‰”minâ¡{m,mâ€²,mâˆ—}â‰”Â¯ğ‘šğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘šâ€²superscriptğ‘š\underline{m}\coloneqq\min\{m,m^{\prime},m^{*}\}underÂ¯ start_ARG italic_m end_ARG â‰” roman_min { italic_m , italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } highlights three components that are in tension: a buyer-defined decision margin ÎµÎ¥subscriptğœ€Î¥\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, a bias requirement Îµbiassubscriptğœ€bias\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the MMD estimator (LemmaÂ 1), and the minimum size mÂ¯Â¯ğ‘š\underline{m}underÂ¯ start_ARG italic_m end_ARG of the vendorsâ€™ sample datasets (assuming mâˆ—â‰¥maxâ¡{m,mâ€²}superscriptğ‘šğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘šâ€²m^{*}\geq\max\{m,m^{\prime}\}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ roman_max { italic_m , italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }). If the buyer requires a higher decision margin ÎµÎ¥subscriptğœ€Î¥\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., the buyer wants to determine if Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P is more valuable than Pâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P^{\prime}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by a larger margin), then it may be necessary to (i) set a lower bias requirement Îµbiassubscriptğœ€bias\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and/or (ii) request larger sample datasets from the vendors. In (i), suppose mÂ¯Â¯ğ‘š\underline{m}underÂ¯ start_ARG italic_m end_ARG remains unchanged, a lower Îµbiassubscriptğœ€bias\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT reduces the confidence level 1âˆ’2â¢Î´12ğ›¿1-2\delta1 - 2 italic_Î´ since Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ increases as Îµbiassubscriptğœ€bias\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT decreases. Hence, although the buyer concludes that Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P is more valuable than Pâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P^{\prime}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by a higher decision margin, the corresponding confidence level is lower. In (ii), suppose Îµbiassubscriptğœ€bias\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT remains unchanged, a higher minimum sample size mÂ¯Â¯ğ‘š\underline{m}underÂ¯ start_ARG italic_m end_ARG increases the confidence level.222In proof of 1, it is shown that the confidence level strictly increases when mğ‘šmitalic_m or mâ€²superscriptğ‘šâ€²m^{\prime}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT increases. In other words, to satisfy the buyerâ€™s higher decision margin, the vendors need to provide larger sample datasets. This can also help the buyer increase their confidence level if the criterion is satisfied. 1 illustrates the interaction between a buyer and data vendors: The buyerâ€™s requirement is represented by the decision margin, and the vendors must provide sufficiently large sample datasets to satisfy this requirement.

4.2 Approximating the Reference Distribution

Previously we assumed Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT could be accessed as the reference. We now relax this assumption by replacing Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with a mixture distribution PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over all the vendorsâ€™ distributions, as defined in 1. We first prove an error guarantee to generalize 1 when using PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT instead of Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We then use a game-theoretic formulation to motivate the choice of the uniform mixture, PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Formally, using PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the reference (with DÏ‰âˆ¼PÏ‰similar-tosubscriptğ·ğœ”subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”D_{\omega}\sim P_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) instead of Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT gives the following valuation:

Î¥^â¢(P)â‰”âˆ’dâ¢(P,PÏ‰),Î½^â¢(D)â‰”âˆ’d^â¢(D,DÏ‰).formulae-sequenceâ‰”^Î¥ğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”â‰”^ğœˆğ·^ğ‘‘ğ·subscriptğ·ğœ”\hat{\Upsilon}(P)\coloneqq-d(P,P_{\omega})\ ,\quad\hat{\nu}(D)\coloneqq-\hat{d% }(D,D_{\omega})\ .over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG ( italic_P ) â‰” - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , over^ start_ARG italic_Î½ end_ARG ( italic_D ) â‰” - over^ start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (3)

Namely, Î¥^^Î¥\hat{\Upsilon}over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG is an approximation to Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ (equiv.Â Î½^^ğœˆ\hat{\nu}over^ start_ARG italic_Î½ end_ARG to Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½), with a bounded (approximation) error as follows,

Proposition 2.

Recall ÎµÏ‰,QÏ‰subscriptğœ€ğœ”subscriptğ‘„ğœ”\varepsilon_{\omega},Q_{\omega}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from 1. Then, âˆ€P,|Î¥â¢(P)âˆ’Î¥^â¢(P)|â‰¤ÎµÏ‰â¢dâ¢(QÏ‰,Pâˆ—)for-allğ‘ƒÎ¥ğ‘ƒ^Î¥ğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ€ğœ”ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘„ğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒ\forall P,|\Upsilon(P)-\hat{\Upsilon}(P)|\leq\varepsilon_{\omega}d(Q_{\omega},% P^{*})\ âˆ€ italic_P , | roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) - over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG ( italic_P ) | â‰¤ italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

(Proof in App.Â A) 2 provides an error bound from using PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the reference, which linearly depends on ÎµÏ‰subscriptğœ€ğœ”\varepsilon_{\omega}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and QÏ‰subscriptğ‘„ğœ”Q_{\omega}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: A lower Îµisubscriptğœ€ğ‘–\varepsilon_{i}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has a lower outlier probability) gives a lower ÎµÏ‰subscriptğœ€ğœ”\varepsilon_{\omega}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and a lower dâ¢(Qi,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒd(Q_{i},P^{*})italic_d ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (i.e., Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s outlier component is closer to Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) leads to a lower dâ¢(QÏ‰,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘„ğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒd(Q_{\omega},P^{*})italic_d ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), resulting in a smaller error from using PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the reference. Using this error guarantee, we give our main result, which provides a decision criterion for concluding that for candidate vendor distributions Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and Pâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P^{\prime}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, their valuations satisfy Î¥â¢(P)>Î¥â¢(Pâ€²)+ÎµÎ¥Î¥ğ‘ƒÎ¥superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²subscriptğœ€Î¥\Upsilon(P)>\Upsilon(P^{\prime})+\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) > roman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for some user-specified decision margin ÎµÎ¥subscriptğœ€Î¥\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Unlike 1, this result does not require access to ground truth Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, but instead uses a practically-realizable mixture PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Theorem 1.

Given datasets Dâˆ¼Psimilar-toğ·ğ‘ƒD\sim Pitalic_D âˆ¼ italic_P and Dâ€²âˆ¼Pâ€²similar-tosuperscriptğ·â€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²D^{\prime}\sim P^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, let mâ‰”|D|â‰”ğ‘šğ·m\coloneqq|D|italic_m â‰” | italic_D | and mâ€²â‰”|Dâ€²|â‰”superscriptğ‘šâ€²superscriptğ·â€²m^{\prime}\coloneqq|D^{\prime}|italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” | italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT |. Î”Î¥,Î½â€²=Î”Î¥,Î½+2â¢ÎµÏ‰â¢dâ¢(QÏ‰,Pâˆ—)subscriptsuperscriptÎ”â€²Î¥ğœˆsubscriptÎ”Î¥ğœˆ2subscriptğœ€ğœ”ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘„ğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒ\Delta^{\prime}_{\Upsilon,\nu}=\Delta_{\Upsilon,\nu}+2\varepsilon_{\omega}d(Q_%
