2 italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )Â . This term explicitly accounts for the statistical difference dâ¢(PÏ‰,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒd(P_{\omega},P^{*})italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) to generalize 1: dâ¢(PÏ‰,Pâˆ—)=0ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒ0d(P_{\omega},P^{*})=0italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 recovers 1. Importantly, this result implies that using PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (to replace Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) retains the previous analysis and interpretation: a buyerâ€™s requirement via the decision margin can be satisfied by the vendors providing (sufficiently) large sample datasets, which is empirically investigated in a comparison against existing valuation methods (Sec.Â 5). We highlight that TheoremÂ 1 exploits the closed property of Huber models (via 1), the triangle inequality of MMD (via 2) and the uniform convergence of the MMD estimator. Hence, the modeling and design choices of Huber and MMD are both necessary.

4.2.1 A Game-theoretic Choice of Mixture

The above results hold for general mixture distributions PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, begging the question: Which mixture should one use (i.e., what Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰)? A game-theoretic formulation reveals that the uniform strategy is worst-case optimal, so we propose to use the uniform mixture PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the special case of PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Consider the following two-player zero-sum game. A payoff matrix â„›â„›\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R consists of nğ‘›nitalic_n rows, one corresponding to each vendor index, and n!ğ‘›n!italic_n ! columns, one corresponding to each permutation over the vendor indices. The row player (i.e., the agent conducting the data valuation) picks a vendor index râˆˆNğ‘Ÿğ‘r\in Nitalic_r âˆˆ italic_N. The column player (hypothetical adversary) then adversarially chooses a permutation Ï€csubscriptğœ‹ğ‘\pi_{c}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over the indices in Nğ‘Nitalic_N. Hence, the action space for the row player is Nğ‘Nitalic_N and that for the column player is all possible permutations of {1,2â¢â€¦,n}12â€¦ğ‘›\{1,2\ldots,n\}{ 1 , 2 â€¦ , italic_n }.444W.l.o.g.Â assume a fixed ordering of all n!ğ‘›n!italic_n ! permutations. The column player represents the fact that the row player lacks prior knowledge about vendors: hence it selects an index rğ‘Ÿritalic_r in any possible arbitrary permutation Ï€csubscriptğœ‹ğ‘\pi_{c}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, for a pair of actions (r,Ï€c)ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘(r,\pi_{c})( italic_r , italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the quality of the distribution PÏ€câ¢[r]subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘ŸP_{\pi_{c}[r]}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the row playerâ€™s payoff â„›r,câ‰”âˆ’dâ¢(Pâˆ—,PÏ€câ¢[r])â‰”subscriptâ„›ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{R}_{r,c}\coloneqq-d(P^{*},P_{\pi_{c}[r]})caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r , italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” - italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), defined as the negated MMD between PÏ€câ¢[r]subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘ŸP_{\pi_{c}[r]}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the optimal distribution Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., a lower MMD means a higher payoff), specifying the following optimization:

maxrâ¡mincâ¡â„›r,csubscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘subscriptâ„›ğ‘Ÿğ‘\textstyle\max_{r}\min_{c}\mathcal{R}_{r,c}roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r , italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (4)

where â„›âˆˆâ„nÃ—(n!)â„›superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›\mathcal{R}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times(n!)}caligraphic_R âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— ( italic_n ! ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the payoff matrix and max\maxroman_max (min\minroman_min) denotes the row (column) playerâ€™s action. A strategy srowâˆˆâ–³â¢(nâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘ rowâ–³ğ‘›1s_{\text{row}}\in\triangle(n-1)italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT row end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ â–³ ( italic_n - 1 ) (as an nğ‘›nitalic_n-dimensional probability vector) specifies the probability with which the row player picks a data vendor (at a position).

While efficient linear program solvers to Eq.Â 4 are available for explicitly specified â„›â„›\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R, in our setting, â„›â„›\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R is not explicitly specified due not knowing Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Fortunately, we show that the uniform strategy is optimal without knowing â„›â„›\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R explicitly:

Proposition 3.

The optimal solution for the row player to Eq.Â 4 is srowâˆ—=[1n,1n,â€¦,1n].subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ row1ğ‘›1ğ‘›â€¦1ğ‘›s^{*}_{\text{row}}=[\frac{1}{n},\frac{1}{n},\ldots,\frac{1}{n}]\ .italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT row end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG , â€¦ , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ] .

(Proof in App.Â A) Intuitively, a uniform strategy over the vendors cannot be exploited by the column player, and is thus worst-case optimal. We highlight that while uniform strategy being worst-case optimal may seem intuitive, the mathematical properties and derivations needed are less straightforward. In particular, the proof depends on the â€œclosedâ€ property of Huber (i.e., 1) and the â€œlinearityâ€ of MMD applied to Huber (i.e., Eq.Â 2) to exploit the strong duality of a linear program. We also discuss alternative formulations to Eq.Â 4 in App.Â A.

Then, we adopt the uniform mixture PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the special case of PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Eq.Â 3:

Î¥^â¢(P)=âˆ’dâ¢(P,PU),Î½^â¢(D)â‰”âˆ’d^â¢(D,DU).formulae-sequence^Î¥ğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒUâ‰”^ğœˆğ·^ğ‘‘ğ·subscriptğ·U\hat{\Upsilon}(P)=-d(P,P_{\text{U}})\ ,\quad\hat{\nu}(D)\coloneqq-\hat{d}(D,D_% {\text{U}})\ .over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG ( italic_P ) = - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , over^ start_ARG italic_Î½ end_ARG ( italic_D ) â‰” - over^ start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (5)

2 and TheoremÂ 1 are applied directly in App.Â A. The uniform mixture PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is inspired from the solutions to Eq.Â 4, which is a game based on not having prior knowledge about the vendors. In this setting of no ground truth and no prior knowledge about the vendors, one might wonder if/how we can derive a lower bound of error to crystalize the difficulty of the problem (our 2 gives an upper bound of error for general PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and CorollaryÂ 1 is for PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). We expand this in App.Â C, making references to robust statistics and mechanism design.

5 Empirical Results

We first compare the sample efficiency of several baselines, and then investigate the effectiveness of our method in ranking nğ‘›nitalic_n data distributions. Additional information on experimental settings is in App.Â C and additional results under non-Huber settings, and on scalability are in App.Â D. Our code is available at https://github.com/XinyiYS/Data_Distribution_Valuation.

Baselines. To accommodate the existing methods which explicitly require a validation set (Sec.Â 2), we perform some experiments using a validation set Dvalâˆ¼Pâˆ—similar-tosubscriptğ·valsuperscriptğ‘ƒD_{\text{val}}\sim P^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This assumption is made only for empirical comparison, and subsequently relaxed. The baselines that explicitly require Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are class-wise Shapley (CS) [55, Eq.Â (3)], LAVA [33] and DAVINZ [66, Eq.Â (3)]; the baselines that do not require Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are information-gain value (IG) [56, Eq.Â (1)], volume value (VV) [69, Eq.Â (2)] and MMD2 [59, Eq.Â (1)], which implements a biased estimator of MMD2. For each baseline, we adopt their official implementation if available. Note that though theoretically MMD2 is obtained by squaring MMD, the estimator for MMD2 is not obtained by squaring the MMD estimator (elaborated in App.Â B), so they give different results. Note that DAVINZ also includes the MMD as a specific implementation choice, linearly combined with a neural tangent kernelÂ (NTK)-based score. However, their theoretical results are specific to NTK and not MMD, while our result (e.g., TheoremÂ 1) is MMD-specific.

Our implementation of MMD, including the radial basis function kernel, follows [42]. To implement our proposed uniform mixture PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in cases where Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s have different sizes, we do the following: denote the minimum dataset size by mminâ‰”miniâ¡|Di|â‰”subscriptğ‘šminsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ·ğ‘–m_{\text{min}}\coloneqq\min_{i}|D_{i}|italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |. Then for each Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, uniformly randomly sample a subset Di,subâŠ†Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–subsubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i,\text{sub}}\subseteq D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , sub end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of size mminsubscriptğ‘šminm_{\text{min}}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and use the union DUâ‰”âˆªiDi,subâ‰”subscriptğ·Usubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ·ğ‘–subD_{\text{U}}\coloneqq\cup_{i}D_{i,\text{sub}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” âˆª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , sub end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Datasets. We consider both classification (Cla.) and regression (Reg.) since some baselines (i.e., CS, LAVA) are specific to classification while some (i.e., IG, VV) are specific to regression. Our method is applicable to both. CaliH (resp.Â KingH) is a housing prices dataset in California [35] (resp.Â in Kings county [28]). Census15 (resp.Â Census17) is a personal income prediction dataset from the 2015 (resp.Â 2017) US census. [48]. Credit7 [49] and Credit31 [3] are two credit card fraud detection datasets. TON [47] and UGR16 [45] are two network intrusion detection datasets.

Many of our evaluations are conducted under a Huber model, which requires matched supports of Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q, such as MNIST, EMNIST and FaMNIST, all in â„32Ã—32superscriptâ„3232\mathbb{R}^{32\times 32}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 32 Ã— 32 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, and Census15 and Census17. Other datasets require additional pre-processing: CaliH and KingH are standardized and pre-processed separately to be in â„10superscriptâ„10\mathbb{R}^{10}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Additional pre-processing details in App.Â D. Subsequently, each Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follows a Huber: Pi=(1âˆ’Îµi)â¢Pâˆ—+Îµiâ¢Qsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–1subscriptğœ€ğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ€ğ‘–ğ‘„P_{i}=(1-\varepsilon_{i})P^{*}+\varepsilon_{i}Qitalic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q (i.e., âˆ€i,Qi=Qfor-allğ‘–subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–ğ‘„\forall i,Q_{i}=Qâˆ€ italic_i , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Q). We also run experiments on non-Huber settings in App.Â D, where our method remains effective.

ML model ğŒğŒ\mathbf{M}bold_M. For model-specific baselines such as DAVINZ and CS, in Sec.Â 5.2, we adopt a 2222-layer convolutional neural network (CNN) for MNIST, EMNIST, FaMNIST; ResNet-18Â [29] for CIFAR10 and CIFAR100; logistic regression (LogReg) for Credit7 and Credit31, and TON and UGR16; linear regression (LR) for CaliH and KingH, and Census15 and Census17. Details are in App.Â D.

5.1 Sample Efficiency via Empirical Convergence

Our goal is to find a sample-efficient policy that correctly compares Î¥â¢(P)Î¥ğ‘ƒ\Upsilon(P)roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) vs.Â Î¥â¢(Pâ€²)Î¥superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\Upsilon(P^{\prime})roman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) by comparing Î½â¢(D)ğœˆğ·\nu(D)italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) vs.Â Î½â¢(Dâ€²)ğœˆsuperscriptğ·â€²\nu(D^{\prime})italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), even if the sizes of D,Dâ€²ğ·superscriptğ·â€²D,D^{\prime}italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are small. In practice, there is no direct access to P,Pâ€²ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P,P^{\prime}italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT but only D,Dâ€²ğ·superscriptğ·â€²D,D^{\prime}italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; the sizes of D,Dâ€²ğ·superscriptğ·â€²D,D^{\prime}italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT may not be very large. Here, we compare {Î½â¢(Di)}iâˆˆNsubscriptğœˆsubscriptğ·ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘\{\nu(D_{i})\}_{i\in N}{ italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to {Î¥â¢(Pi)}iâˆˆNsubscriptÎ¥subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘\{\Upsilon(P_{i})\}_{i\in N}{ roman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as we vary dataset size misubscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Setting. We implement Î¥â¢(Pi)Î¥subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–\Upsilon(P_{i})roman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) as approximated by a Î½â¢(Diâˆ—)ğœˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘–\nu(D_{i}^{*})italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) where Diâˆ—âˆ¼Pisimilar-tosuperscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–D_{i}^{*}\sim P_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with a large size miâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i}^{*}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (e.g., 10,0001000010,00010 , 000 for Pâˆ—=superscriptğ‘ƒabsentP^{*}=italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = MNIST vs.Â Q=ğ‘„absentQ=italic_Q = EMNIST). Denote the values of the samples as ğ‚miâ‰”{Î½â¢(Di)}iâˆˆNâ‰”subscriptğ‚subscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscriptğœˆsubscriptğ·ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘\boldsymbol{\nu}_{m_{i}}\coloneqq\{\nu(D_{i})\}_{i\in N}bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” { italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where the sample size mi=|Di|subscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscriptğ·ğ‘–m_{i}=|D_{i}|italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = | italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | and the approximated ground truths as ğ‚âˆ—â‰”{Î½â¢(Diâˆ—)}iâˆˆNâ‰”superscriptğ‚subscriptğœˆsubscriptsuperscriptğ·ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘\boldsymbol{\nu}^{*}\coloneqq\{\nu(D^{*}_{i})\}_{i\in N}bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” { italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; in this way, ğ‚âˆ—superscriptğ‚\boldsymbol{\nu}^{*}bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is well-defined respectively for each comparison baseline (i.e., not our MMD definition Eq.Â 1). We highlight that each Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½ (i.e., each baseline) is evaluated against its corresponding ğ‚âˆ—superscriptğ‚\boldsymbol{\nu}^{*}bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to demonstrate the empirical convergence. This is to examine the practical applicability of each Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½ when the sizes of the provided {Di}iâˆˆNsubscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘\{D_{i}\}_{i\in N}{ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are limited.

Evaluation and results. We evaluate three criteriaâ€”the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â„“âˆsubscriptâ„“\ell_{\infty}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT errors and the number of pair-wise inversions as follows, â€–ğ‚miâˆ’ğ‚âˆ—â€–2,â€–ğ‚miâˆ’ğ‚âˆ—â€–âˆsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‚subscriptğ‘šğ‘–superscriptğ‚2subscriptnormsubscriptğ‚subscriptğ‘šğ‘–superscriptğ‚\|\boldsymbol{\nu}_{m_{i}}-\boldsymbol{\nu}^{*}\|_{2},\|\boldsymbol{\nu}_{m_{i% }}-\boldsymbol{\nu}^{*}\|_{\infty}âˆ¥ bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and inversionsâ¢(ğ‚mi,ğ‚âˆ—)â‰”(1/2)â¢âˆ‘i,iâ€²âˆˆ[n],iâ‰ iâ€²ğŸ™â¢(Î½â¢(Diâˆ—)>Î½â¢(Diâ€²âˆ—)âˆ§Î½â¢(Di)<Î½â¢(Diâ€²)).â‰”inversionssubscriptğ‚subscriptğ‘šğ‘–superscriptğ‚12subscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘–superscriptğ‘–â€²delimited-[]ğ‘›ğ‘–superscriptğ‘–â€²1ğœˆsubscriptsuperscriptğ·ğ‘–ğœˆsubscriptsuperscriptğ·superscriptğ‘–â€²ğœˆsubscriptğ·ğ‘–ğœˆsubscriptğ·superscriptğ‘–â€²\texttt{inversions}(\boldsymbol{\nu}_{m_{i}},\boldsymbol{\nu}^{*})\coloneqq(1/% 2)\sum_{i,i^{\prime}\in[n],i\neq i^{\prime}}\mathbbm{1}(\nu(D^{*}_{i})>\nu(D^{% *}_{i^{\prime}})\wedge\nu(D_{i})<\nu(D_{i^{\prime}})).inversions ( bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰” ( 1 / 2 ) âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ [ italic_n ] , italic_i â‰  italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 ( italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ§ italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) < italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) . In words, if the conclusion via Î½â¢(Di)ğœˆsubscriptğ·ğ‘–\nu(D_{i})italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) vs.Â Î½â¢(Diâ€²)ğœˆsubscriptğ·superscriptğ‘–â€²\nu(D_{i^{\prime}})italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) differs from that via Î½â¢(Diâˆ—)ğœˆsubscriptsuperscriptğ·ğ‘–\nu(D^{*}_{i})italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) vs.Â Î½â¢(Diâ€²âˆ—)ğœˆsubscriptsuperscriptğ·superscriptğ‘–â€²\nu(D^{*}_{i^{\prime}})italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), it is an inversion. For all 3333 criteria, lower is better.

Fig.Â 1 (and Figs.Â 2, 5, 4 andÂ 3 in App.Â D) demonstrate that our MMD-based method is overall (one of) the most sample-efficient for different evaluation criteria and datasets, validating the theoretical results (TableÂ 1) that MMD is more sample-efficient than WD.

5.2 Ranking Data Distributions

Motivated by the use-case of a buyer identifying the best data vendor(s), we measure our ability to rank nğ‘›nitalic_n distributions based on the values of sample datasets.

Setting. For a valuation metric Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½ (e.g., Eq.Â 1), denote the values of datasets from all vendors as ğ‚â‰”{Î½â¢(Di)}iâˆˆNâ‰”ğ‚subscriptğœˆsubscriptğ·ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘\boldsymbol{\nu}\coloneqq\{\nu(D_{i})\}_{i\in N}bold_italic_Î½ â‰” { italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To compare against different baselines (i.e., other definitions of Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½), we define the following common ground truth, the expected test performance Î¶iâ‰”ğ”¼Diâˆ¼Piâ¢[Perfâ¢(ğŒâ¢(Di);Dtest)]â‰”subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğ”¼similar-tosubscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–delimited-[]PerfğŒsubscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ·test\zeta_{i}\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{D_{i}\sim P_{i}}[\text{Perf}(\mathbf{M}(D_{i});D% _{\text{test}})]italic_Î¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ Perf ( bold_M ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ; italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT test end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] of an ML model ğŒâ¢(Di)ğŒsubscriptğ·ğ‘–\mathbf{M}(D_{i})bold_M ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) trained on Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, over a fixed test set Dtestsubscriptğ·testD_{\text{test}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT test end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where the expectation is over the randomness of Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let ğœ»â‰”{Î¶i}iâˆˆNâ‰”ğœ»subscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘\boldsymbol{\zeta}\coloneqq\{\zeta_{i}\}_{i\in N}bold_italic_Î¶ â‰” { italic_Î¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The ML model ğŒğŒ\mathbf{M}bold_M is specified previously and the test set Dtestsubscriptğ·testD_{\text{test}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT test end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is from the respective Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and not seen by any data vendor. Note that Dtestsubscriptğ·testD_{\text{test}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT test end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is used to obtain Î¶isubscriptğœğ‘–\zeta_{i}italic_Î¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for comparison purposes, and it is not to be confused with Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is required by some baselines as part of their methods.

Utilizing labels. We also extend our method to explicitly consider the label information via the conditional distributions of labels given features (i.e., PY|Xsubscriptğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘Œğ‘‹P_{Y|X}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y | italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), denoted as Ours cond. Other baselines such as LAVA and CS already explicitly use label information. Specifically, for Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT containing paired features and labels, we fit a learner ğŒâ¢(Di)ğŒsubscriptğ·ğ‘–\mathbf{M}(D_{i})bold_M ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) on Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and use its predictions on Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (thus we require Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) as an empirical representation of the PY|Xsubscriptğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘Œğ‘‹P_{Y|X}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y | italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and compute the MMD between the conditional distributions (more implementation details in App.Â D). Unlike our original method (i.e., Ours), this variant differs in exploiting the feature-label pairs in Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We relax the assumption Dvalâˆ¼Pâˆ—similar-tosubscriptğ·valsuperscriptğ‘ƒD_{\text{val}}\sim P^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by replacing Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with DUsubscriptğ·UD_{\text{U}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, namely for the baselines needing an explicit reference, we use DUsubscriptğ·UD_{\text{U}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The resulting data values are denoted as ğ‚^bold-^ğ‚\boldsymbol{\hat{\nu}}overbold_^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î½ end_ARG (the data values based on Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are denoted as ğ‚ğ‚\boldsymbol{\nu}bold_italic_Î½).

Evaluation metric. Here Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½ is effective if it identifies the most valuable sampling distribution, or more generally, if ğ‚ğ‚\boldsymbol{\nu}bold_italic_Î½ preserves the ranking of ğœ»ğœ»\boldsymbol{\zeta}bold_italic_Î¶. In other words, the ranking of the data vendorsâ€™ sampling distributions {Pi}iâˆˆNsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘\{P_{i}\}_{i\in N}{ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is correctly identified by the values of their datasets {Di}iâˆˆNsubscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘\{D_{i}\}_{i\in N}{ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, quantified via the Pearson correlation coefficient: Ïâ¢(ğ‚,ğœ»)ğœŒğ‚ğœ»\rho(\boldsymbol{\nu},\boldsymbol{\zeta})italic_Ï ( bold_italic_Î½ , bold_italic_Î¶ ) (higher is better). Note that we compare the rankings of different baselines instead of the actual data values which can be on different scales.

Results. We report the average and standard error over 5555 independent random trials, on CIFAR10/CIFAR100, TON/UGR16, CaliH/KingH and Census15/Census17 in TablesÂ 2 andÂ 3 respectively, and defer the others to App.Â D. Note that when Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is unavailable (i.e., right columns), Ours cond. is not applicable because the label-feature pair information is not well-defined under the Huber model (e.g., for Pâˆ—=superscriptğ‘ƒabsentP^{*}=italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = CIFAR10 vs.Â Q=ğ‘„absentQ=italic_Q = CIFAR100, the label of a CIFAR100 image is not well-defined for a model trained for CIFAR10). The Perfâ¢(â‹…)Perfâ‹…\text{Perf}(\cdot)Perf ( â‹… ) for ğœ»ğœ»\boldsymbol{\zeta}bold_italic_Î¶ for classification (resp.Â regression) is accuracy (resp.Â coefficient of determination (COD)), so higher is better.

For classification, TableÂ 2 shows that our method performs well when Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is available (e.g., Ours cond. is the highest for CIFAR10 vs.Â CIFAR100 under Ïâ¢(ğ‚,ğœ»)ğœŒğ‚ğœ»\rho(\boldsymbol{\nu},\boldsymbol{\zeta})italic_Ï ( bold_italic_Î½ , bold_italic_Î¶ )) and also when Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is unavailable (e.g., Ours as highest for CIFAR10 vs.Â CIFAR100 under Ïâ¢(ğ‚^,ğœ»)ğœŒbold-^ğ‚ğœ»\rho(\boldsymbol{\hat{\nu}},\boldsymbol{\zeta})italic_Ï ( overbold_^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î½ end_ARG , bold_italic_Î¶ )). MMD2 performs comparably to Ours, which is expected since in theory their values differ only by a square and the evaluation mainly focuses on the rank, instead of the absolute values. We also note that CS, by exploiting the label information in classification, performs competitively with Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but performs sub-optimally without Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is because the label information in Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is no longer available in DÏ‰subscriptğ·ğœ”D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (due to DÏ‰subscriptğ·ğœ”D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT being Huber). LAVA and DAVINZ, both exploiting the gradients of the ML model, do not perform well. The reason could be that under the Huber model, the gradients are not as informative about the values of the data. Intuitively, while the gradient of (the loss of) a data point on an ML model can be informative about the value of this data point, this reasoning is not applicable here, because the data point may not be from the same true distribution Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: The value of a gradient obtained on a CIFAR100 image to an ML model intended for CIFAR10 may not be informative about the value of this CIFAR100 image. We highlight that neither of LAVA and DAVINZ was originally proposed for such cases (i.e., the Huber model).

For regression, TableÂ 3 shows that Ours and MMD2 continue to perform well while baselines (i.e., IG and VV) that completely remove the reference perform poorly, as they cannot account for the statistical heterogeneity without a reference. Notably, DAVINZ performs competitively for when Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is available, due to its implementation utilizing a linear combination of an NTK-based score (i.e., gradient information) and MMD (similar to Ours), via an auto-tuned weight between the two. We find that for classification, the NTK-based score is dominant while for regression (and available Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) the MMD is dominant. This could be because the models are more complex for the classification tasks (e.g., ResNet-18) as compared to linear regression models for regression, so the obtained gradients are more significant (i.e., higher numerical NTK-based scores). Thus, for regression, DAVINZ produces values similar to Ours, hence the similar performance. We highlight that DAVINZ focuses on the use of NTK w.r.t.Â a given reference, while our method focuses on MMD without such a reference, as evidenced by Ours outperforming DAVINZ without Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., the columns under Ïâ¢(ğ‚^,ğœ»)ğœŒbold-^ğ‚ğœ»\rho(\boldsymbol{\hat{\nu}},\boldsymbol{\zeta})italic_Ï ( overbold_^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î½ end_ARG , bold_italic_Î¶ ) in TableÂ 3).

6 Discussion

Under a Huber model of vendor heterogeneity, we propose an MMD-based data distribution valuation and derive theoretically-justified policies for comparing distributions from their respective samples. To address the lack of access to the true reference distribution, we use a convex mixture of the vendorsâ€™ distributions as the reference, and derive a corresponding error guarantee and comparison policy. Then, we specifically select the uniform mixture as a game-theoretic choice when no prior knowledge about the vendors is assumed. Empirical results demonstrate that our method performs well in efficiently identifying the most valuable data distribution. While our theoretical results are limited to the Huber model, MMD is observed to be effective under two non-Huber settingsÂ (Sec.Â D.3.4). Extending the theory to more general heterogeneity models is an interesting direction for future study.

Appendix A Proofs and Derivations

A.1 Equivalent Definitions of MMD

DefinitionÂ 1 follows [26] to use the function class â„±â„±\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F. In our derivation and implementations, we adopt an equivalent but more convenient form utilizing the kernel and mean embedding [26, Section 2.2]. DefinitionÂ 1 is more difficult to use with because of the supsupremum\suproman_sup operation. Specifically, recall that â„±â„±\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F is a class of functions in the unit ball of reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS) â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H}caligraphic_H which is associated with the kernel kğ‘˜kitalic_k, then the following equivalence holdsÂ [26, LemmaÂ 6]:

dâ¢(P,Pâ€²;â„±)={ğ”¼X,Xâ€²âˆ¼Pâ¢[kâ¢(X,Xâ€²)]âˆ’2â¢ğ”¼Xâˆ¼P,Yâˆ¼Pâ€²â¢[kâ¢(X,Y)]+ğ”¼Y,Yâ€²âˆ¼Pâ€²â¢[kâ¢(Y,Yâ€²)]}1/2.ğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²â„±superscriptsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘‹superscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]ğ‘˜ğ‘‹superscriptğ‘‹â€²2subscriptğ”¼formulae-sequencesimilar-toğ‘‹ğ‘ƒsimilar-toğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²delimited-[]ğ‘˜ğ‘‹ğ‘Œsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘Œâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²delimited-[]ğ‘˜ğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘Œâ€²12d(P,P^{\prime};\mathcal{F})=\left\{\mathbb{E}_{X,X^{\prime}\sim P}[k(X,X^{% \prime})]-2\mathbb{E}_{X\sim P,Y\sim P^{\prime}}[k(X,Y)]+\mathbb{E}_{Y,Y^{% \prime}\sim P^{\prime}}[k(Y,Y^{\prime})]\right\}^{1/2}\ .italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_F ) = { blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X , italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k ( italic_X , italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] - 2 blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X âˆ¼ italic_P , italic_Y âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k ( italic_X , italic_Y ) ] + blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k ( italic_Y , italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (6)

The definition of MMD that is used in our derivation and implementation is the right hand side above. This definition is more convenient because it no longer has the unwieldy supsupremum\suproman_sup operation and is interpretable (i.e., resembling the square root of an expanded quadratic expression).

We note that throughout the paper, the class â„±â„±\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F of functions, its corresponding RKHS â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H}caligraphic_H and the associated kernel kğ‘˜kitalic_k are all kept constant, so their notational dependence is omitted where clear for brevity.

A.2 For Sec.Â 3

Proof of 1.
Proof of 1.

Note that PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a mixture model/distribution, as it is a convex combination of Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s. The expressions for ÎµN,QNsubscriptğœ€ğ‘subscriptğ‘„ğ‘\varepsilon_{N},Q_{N}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are derived as follows,

PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”\displaystyle P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰”âˆ‘iâˆˆNÏ‰iâ¢[(1âˆ’Îµi)â¢Pâˆ—+Îµiâ¢Qi]â‰”absentsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğœ”ğ‘–delimited-[]1subscriptğœ€ğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ€ğ‘–subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–\displaystyle\coloneqq\sum_{i\in N}\omega_{i}[(1-\varepsilon_{i})P^{*}+% \varepsilon_{i}Q_{i}]â‰” âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( 1 - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]
=Pâˆ—â¢âˆ‘iâˆˆNÏ‰iâ¢(1âˆ’Îµi)+(âˆ‘iâˆˆNÏ‰iâ¢Îµiâ¢Qi)absentsuperscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğœ”ğ‘–1subscriptğœ€ğ‘–subscriptğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğœ”ğ‘–subscriptğœ€ğ‘–subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–\displaystyle=P^{*}\sum_{i\in N}\omega_{i}(1-\varepsilon_{i})+(\sum_{i\in N}% \omega_{i}\varepsilon_{i}Q_{i})= italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
=Pâˆ—(1âˆ’âˆ‘iâˆˆNÏ‰iâ¢ÎµiâŸÎµÏ‰)+(âˆ‘iâˆˆNÏ‰iÎµiQi)âŸÎµÏ‰â¢QÏ‰.\displaystyle=P^{*}(1-\underbrace{\sum_{i\in N}\omega_{i}\varepsilon_{i}}_{% \varepsilon_{\omega}})+(\underbrace{\sum_{i\in N}\omega_{i}\varepsilon_{i}Q_{i% })}_{\varepsilon_{\omega}Q_{\omega}}\ .= italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - underâŸ start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ( underâŸ start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

The last step uses the fact that the entries of a probability vector Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ sum up to 1111Â . âˆ

A.3 For Sec.Â 4.1

Useful lemma.
Lemma 1 (Uniform Convergence of MMD EstimatorÂ [26, Theorem 7]).

Let Xâˆ¼P,Wâˆ¼Pâ€²formulae-sequencesimilar-toğ‘‹ğ‘ƒsimilar-toğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²X\sim P,W\sim P^{\prime}italic_X âˆ¼ italic_P , italic_W âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the size of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is mğ‘šmitalic_m, the size of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is nğ‘›nitalic_n. Then the biased MMD estimator d^^ğ‘‘\hat{d}over^ start_ARG italic_d end_ARG satisfies the following approximation guarantee:

PrX,Wâ¢{|d^â¢(X,W)âˆ’dâ¢(P,Pâ€²)|>2â¢(K/m+K/n)+Îµ}â‰¤2â¢expâ¡(âˆ’Îµ2â¢mâ¢n2â¢Kâ¢(m+n))subscriptPrğ‘‹ğ‘Š^ğ‘‘ğ‘‹ğ‘Šğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²2ğ¾ğ‘šğ¾ğ‘›ğœ€2superscriptğœ€2ğ‘šğ‘›2ğ¾ğ‘šğ‘›\text{Pr}_{X,W}\left\{|\hat{d}(X,W)-d(P,P^{\prime})|>2(\sqrt{K/m}+\sqrt{K/n})+% \varepsilon\right\}\leq 2\exp(\frac{-\varepsilon^{2}mn}{2K(m+n)})Pr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X , italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { | over^ start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ( italic_X , italic_W ) - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | > 2 ( square-root start_ARG italic_K / italic_m end_ARG + square-root start_ARG italic_K / italic_n end_ARG ) + italic_Îµ } â‰¤ 2 roman_exp ( divide start_ARG - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K ( italic_m + italic_n ) end_ARG )

where PrX,WsubscriptPrğ‘‹ğ‘Š\text{Pr}_{X,W}Pr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X , italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is over the randomness of the mğ‘šmitalic_m-sample Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and nğ‘›nitalic_n-sample Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W.

Note that Îµbiassubscriptğœ€bias\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in our results (e.g., 1) corresponds to Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ in LemmaÂ 1.

Proof of 1.
Proof of 1.

Apply LemmaÂ 1 to Dâˆ¼Psimilar-toğ·ğ‘ƒD\sim Pitalic_D âˆ¼ italic_P and Dâˆ¼Pâ€²similar-toğ·superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²D\sim P^{\prime}italic_D âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively.

W.p.Â â‰¥1âˆ’Î´Pabsent1subscriptğ›¿ğ‘ƒ\geq 1-\delta_{P}â‰¥ 1 - italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where Î´Pâ‰”2â¢expâ¡(âˆ’Îµbias2â¢mâ¢mâˆ—2â¢Kâ¢(m+mâˆ—))â‰”subscriptğ›¿ğ‘ƒ2subscriptsuperscriptğœ€2biasğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘š2ğ¾ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘š\delta_{P}\coloneqq 2\exp(\frac{-\varepsilon^{2}_{\text{bias}}mm^{*}}{2K(m+m^{% *})})italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” 2 roman_exp ( divide start_ARG - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K ( italic_m + italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG ),

dâ¢(P,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒ\displaystyle d(P,P^{*})italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤d^â¢(D,Dâˆ—)+[2â¢(Km+Kmâˆ—)+Îµbias]absent^ğ‘‘ğ·superscriptğ·delimited-[]2ğ¾ğ‘šğ¾superscriptğ‘šsubscriptğœ€bias\displaystyle\leq\hat{d}(D,D^{*})+[2(\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}}+\sqrt{\frac{K}{m^{*}}}% )+\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}]â‰¤ over^ start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + [ 2 ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ) + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]

where the first inequality is from directly applying LemmaÂ 1, the second inequality is from substituting the definitions in Eq.Â 1.

Symmetrically, w.p.Â â‰¥1âˆ’Î´Pâ€²absent1subscriptğ›¿superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\geq 1-\delta_{P^{\prime}}â‰¥ 1 - italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where Î´Pâ€²â‰”2â¢expâ¡(âˆ’Îµbias2â¢mâ€²â¢mâˆ—2â¢Kâ¢(mâ€²+mâˆ—))â‰”subscriptğ›¿superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²2subscriptsuperscriptğœ€2biassuperscriptğ‘šâ€²superscriptğ‘š2ğ¾superscriptğ‘šâ€²superscriptğ‘š\delta_{P^{\prime}}\coloneqq 2\exp(\frac{-\varepsilon^{2}_{\text{bias}}m^{% \prime}m^{*}}{2K(m^{\prime}+m^{*})})italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” 2 roman_exp ( divide start_ARG - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K ( italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG ),

Î¥â¢(Pâ€²)â‰¤Î½â¢(Dâ€²)+[2â¢(Kmâ€²+Kmâˆ—)+Îµbias]âŸB.Î¥superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²subscriptâŸğœˆsuperscriptğ·â€²delimited-[]2ğ¾superscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ¾superscriptğ‘šsubscriptğœ€biasğµ\Upsilon(P^{\prime})\leq\underbrace{\nu(D^{\prime})+[2(\sqrt{\frac{K}{m^{% \prime}}}+\sqrt{\frac{K}{m^{*}}})+\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}]}_{B}\ .roman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ underâŸ start_ARG italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + [ 2 ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ) + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Î½â¢(D)âˆ’[2â¢(Km+Kmâˆ—)+Îµbias]ğœˆğ·delimited-[]2ğ¾ğ‘šğ¾superscriptğ‘šsubscriptğœ€bias\displaystyle\nu(D)-[2(\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}}+\sqrt{\frac{K}{m^{*}}})+\varepsilon_% {\text{bias}}]italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) - [ 2 ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ) + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] â‰¥Î½â¢(Dâ€²)+[2â¢(Kmâ€²+Kmâˆ—)+Îµbias]+ÎµÎ¥absentğœˆsuperscriptğ·â€²delimited-[]2ğ¾superscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ¾superscriptğ‘šsubscriptğœ€biassubscriptğœ€Î¥\displaystyle\geq\nu(D^{\prime})+[2(\sqrt{\frac{K}{m^{\prime}}}+\sqrt{\frac{K}% {m^{*}}})+\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}]+\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}â‰¥ italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + [ 2 ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ) + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
Î½â¢(D)ğœˆğ·\displaystyle\nu(D)italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) â‰¥Î½â¢(Dâ€²)+2â¢[Îµbias+Km+Kmâ€²+2â¢Kmâˆ—]âŸÎ¶Î½+ÎµÎ¥.absentğœˆsuperscriptğ·â€²subscriptâŸ2delimited-[]subscriptğœ€biasğ¾ğ‘šğ¾superscriptğ‘šâ€²2ğ¾superscriptğ‘šsubscriptğœğœˆsubscriptğœ€Î¥\displaystyle\geq\nu(D^{\prime})+\underbrace{2[\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}+\sqrt% {\frac{K}{m}}+\sqrt{\frac{K}{m^{\prime}}}+2\sqrt{\frac{K}{m^{*}}}]}_{\zeta_{% \nu}}+\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}\ .â‰¥ italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + underâŸ start_ARG 2 [ italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG + 2 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ] end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

To arrive at the simpler but slightly looser result in the main paper. Note that

(1âˆ’Î´P)â¢(1âˆ’Î´Pâ€²)â‰¥(1âˆ’Î´)2â‰¥(1âˆ’2â¢Î´).1subscriptğ›¿ğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ›¿superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²superscript1ğ›¿212ğ›¿(1-\delta_{P})(1-\delta_{P^{\prime}})\geq(1-\delta)^{2}\geq(1-2\delta)\ .( 1 - italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( 1 - italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¥ ( 1 - italic_Î´ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ ( 1 - 2 italic_Î´ ) .

Confidence level increases with m,mâ€²ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘šâ€²m,m^{\prime}italic_m , italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that equivalently,

Î´P=2â¢expâ¡(âˆ’Îµbias2â¢mâˆ—2â¢K+Îµbias2â¢mâˆ—22â¢Kâ¢(m+mâˆ—)),subscriptğ›¿ğ‘ƒ2superscriptsubscriptğœ€bias2superscriptğ‘š2ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğœ€bias2superscriptğ‘šabsent22ğ¾ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘š\delta_{P}=2\exp(-\frac{\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}^{2}m^{*}}{2K}+\frac{% \varepsilon_{\text{bias}}^{2}m^{*2}}{2K(m+m^{*})})\ ,italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K ( italic_m + italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) ,

which is decreasing in mğ‘šmitalic_m. Similarly for Î´Pâ€²subscriptğ›¿superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\delta_{P^{\prime}}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT w.r.t.Â mâ€²superscriptğ‘šâ€²m^{\prime}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A.4 For Sec.Â 4.2

Useful lemma.
Lemma 2 ([15, In proof of Lemma 3.3]).

For a Huber model Pâ‰”(1âˆ’Îµ)â¢Pâˆ—+Îµâ¢Qâ‰”ğ‘ƒ1ğœ€superscriptğ‘ƒğœ€ğ‘„P\coloneqq(1-\varepsilon)P^{*}+\varepsilon Qitalic_P â‰” ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Îµ italic_Q, the MMD dâ¢(P,Pâˆ—)=Îµâ¢dâ¢(Pâˆ—,Q)ğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒğœ€ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘„d(P,P^{*})=\varepsilon d(P^{*},Q)italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_Îµ italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q ).

A.4.1 Results and Discussion for a General Mixture PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

Error from using a reference.

Sec.Â 4.2 describes a theoretically justified choice for a reference Prefsubscriptğ‘ƒrefP_{\text{ref}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be used in place of Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ in Eq.Â 1, and define an approximate Î¥^â‰”âˆ’dâ¢(Pref,P)â‰”^Î¥ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒrefğ‘ƒ\hat{\Upsilon}\coloneqq-d(P_{\text{ref}},P)over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG â‰” - italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P ). Then, the valuation error |Î¥â¢(P)âˆ’Î¥^â¢(P)|Î¥ğ‘ƒ^Î¥ğ‘ƒ|\Upsilon(P)-\hat{\Upsilon}(P)|| roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) - over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG ( italic_P ) | from using this reference Prefsubscriptğ‘ƒrefP_{\text{ref}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT should ideally be small. This error is directly upper bounded by the MMD between Prefsubscriptğ‘ƒrefP_{\text{ref}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as follows.

Lemma 3.

For a choice of reference Prefsubscriptğ‘ƒrefP_{\text{ref}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, define Î¥^â¢(P)â‰”âˆ’dâ¢(Pref,P)â‰”^Î¥ğ‘ƒğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒrefğ‘ƒ\hat{\Upsilon}(P)\coloneqq-d(P_{\text{ref}},P)over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG ( italic_P ) â‰” - italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P ) as the approximate version of Î¥â¢(P)Î¥ğ‘ƒ\Upsilon(P)roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) in Eq.Â 1. Then,

âˆ€P,|Î¥â¢(P)âˆ’Î¥^â¢(P)|â‰¤dâ¢(Pref,Pâˆ—).for-allğ‘ƒÎ¥ğ‘ƒ^Î¥ğ‘ƒğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒrefsuperscriptğ‘ƒ\forall P,|\Upsilon(P)-\hat{\Upsilon}(P)|\leq d(P_{\text{ref}},P^{*})\ .âˆ€ italic_P , | roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) - over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG ( italic_P ) | â‰¤ italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .
Proof.

Apply the triangle inequality of MMD to the definitions of Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ and Î¥^^Î¥\hat{\Upsilon}over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG.

|Î¥â¢(P)âˆ’Î¥^â¢(P)|Î¥ğ‘ƒ^Î¥ğ‘ƒ\displaystyle|\Upsilon(P)-\hat{\Upsilon}(P)|| roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) - over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG ( italic_P ) | =|dâ¢(P,Pâˆ—)âˆ’dâ¢(Pref,Pâˆ—)|absentğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒrefsuperscriptğ‘ƒ\displaystyle=|d(P,P^{*})-d(P_{\text{ref}},P^{*})|= | italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) |
â‰¤dâ¢(P,Pref).absentğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒref\displaystyle\leq d(P,P_{\text{ref}})\ .â‰¤ italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

âˆ

LemmaÂ 3 implies that a better reference distribution (i.e., with a lower MMD to Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) leads to a better approximate Î¥^^Î¥\hat{\Upsilon}over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG (i.e., with a lower error). Hence, we have specifically obtained theoretical results to upper bound the MMD between our considered choices for reference: PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT via LemmaÂ 4, which is be directly combined with LemmaÂ 3 to derive the error guarantee, described next.

Error from using PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the reference.

We first provide an upper bound on dâ¢(PÏ‰,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒd(P_{\omega},P^{*})italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in LemmaÂ 4, and then combine it with LemmaÂ 3 to obtain 2.

Lemma 4.

The sampling distribution PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for DÏ‰subscriptğ·ğœ”D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies dâ¢(PÏ‰,Pâˆ—)â‰¤ÎµÏ‰â¢dâ¢(QÏ‰,Pâˆ—).ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ€ğœ”ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘„ğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒd(P_{\omega},P^{*})\leq\varepsilon_{\omega}d(Q_{\omega},P^{*})\ .italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

Proof of LemmaÂ 4.

The proof is a direct application of 1 and LemmaÂ 2. âˆ

LemmaÂ 4 provides an upper bound on the MMD between PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which linearly depends on ÎµÏ‰subscriptğœ€ğœ”\varepsilon_{\omega}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and QÏ‰subscriptğ‘„ğœ”Q_{\omega}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A lower ÎµÏ‰subscriptğœ€ğœ”\varepsilon_{\omega}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or a lower dâ¢(QÏ‰,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘„ğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒd(Q_{\omega},P^{*})italic_d ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) leads to a smaller dâ¢(PÏ‰,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒd(P_{\omega},P^{*})italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), making DÏ‰subscriptğ·ğœ”D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT a better reference.

Proof of 2.

It directly combines LemmaÂ 4 and LemmaÂ 3. âˆ

Proof of TheoremÂ 1.

Apply LemmaÂ 4 and LemmaÂ 1 to Dâˆ¼Psimilar-toğ·ğ‘ƒD\sim Pitalic_D âˆ¼ italic_P and Dâˆ¼Pâ€²similar-toğ·superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²D\sim P^{\prime}italic_D âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively.

W.p.Â â‰¥1âˆ’Î´Pâ€²absent1subscriptsuperscriptğ›¿â€²ğ‘ƒ\geq 1-\delta^{\prime}_{P}â‰¥ 1 - italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where Î´Pâ€²â‰”2â¢expâ¡(âˆ’Îµbias2â¢mâ¢mN2â¢Kâ¢(m+mN))â‰”subscriptsuperscriptğ›¿â€²ğ‘ƒ2subscriptsuperscriptğœ€2biasğ‘šsubscriptğ‘šğ‘2ğ¾ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘šğ‘\delta^{\prime}_{P}\coloneqq 2\exp(\frac{-\varepsilon^{2}_{\text{bias}}mm_{N}}% {2K(m+m_{N})})italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” 2 roman_exp ( divide start_ARG - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K ( italic_m + italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ),

Î½^â¢(D)â‰¥Î½^â¢(Dâ€²)+2â¢[Îµbias+Km+Kmâ€²+2â¢KmN+ÎµÏ‰â¢dâ¢(QÏ‰,Pâˆ—)]âŸÎ¶Î½â€²+ÎµÎ¥.^ğœˆğ·^ğœˆsuperscriptğ·â€²subscriptâŸ2delimited-[]subscriptğœ€biasğ¾ğ‘šğ¾superscriptğ‘šâ€²2ğ¾subscriptğ‘šğ‘subscriptğœ€ğœ”ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘„ğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptsuperscriptğœâ€²ğœˆsubscriptğœ€Î¥\displaystyle\hat{\nu}(D)\geq\hat{\nu}(D^{\prime})+\underbrace{2\left[% \varepsilon_{\text{bias}}+\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}}+\sqrt{\frac{K}{m^{\prime}}}+2% \sqrt{\frac{K}{m_{N}}}+\varepsilon_{\omega}d(Q_{\omega},P^{*})\right]}_{\zeta^% {\prime}_{\nu}}+\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}\ .over^ start_ARG italic_Î½ end_ARG ( italic_D ) â‰¥ over^ start_ARG italic_Î½ end_ARG ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + underâŸ start_ARG 2 [ italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG + 2 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¶ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

To arrive at the simpler but slightly looser result in the main paper, note that

(1âˆ’Î´Pâ€²)â¢(1âˆ’Î´Pâ€²â€²)â‰¥(1âˆ’Î´â€²)2â‰¥(1âˆ’2â¢Î´â€²).1subscriptsuperscriptğ›¿â€²ğ‘ƒ1subscriptsuperscriptğ›¿â€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²superscript1superscriptğ›¿â€²212superscriptğ›¿â€²(1-\delta^{\prime}_{P})(1-\delta^{\prime}_{P^{\prime}})\geq(1-\delta^{\prime})% ^{2}\geq(1-2\delta^{\prime})\ .( 1 - italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( 1 - italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¥ ( 1 - italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ ( 1 - 2 italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

âˆ

A.4.2 Results and Discussion for the Uniform Mixture PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

As we do not make any assumptions about the prior knowledge of the vendors (e.g., some vendor iğ‘–iitalic_i is more reputable), we adopt a perspective that minimizes the worst-case (i.e., maximum) error over selecting the vendorâ€™s distribution as the reference. In other words, we (represented below as the row player) want to pick a vendor, and use the corresponding distribution as the reference to value other distributions. Hence, if we pick a â€œgoodâ€ vendor (i.e., whose distribution is close to Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), it is more desirable (i.e., a higher payoff) since the approximation error (as in 2) is lower. Formally, we construct a finite two-player zero-sum game in which we show that the uniform strategy is worst-case optimal. Hence, we propose to use the uniform mixture PU=1nâ¢âˆ‘iPisubscriptğ‘ƒU1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{\text{U}}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the vendorâ€™s distributions as the specific choice of reference.

A finite, two-player zero-sum game.

The row player (main player) represents the buyer (the one performing valuation) and the column player (hypothetical adversary) is used to explicitly model the fact that we do not have prior knowledge or assumptions about the vendorsâ€™ distributions (except each Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Huber).

Recall that the payoff matrix â„›âˆˆâ„nÃ—(n!)â„›superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›\mathcal{R}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times(n!)}caligraphic_R âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— ( italic_n ! ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for the row player (main player) is

â„›r,câ‰”âˆ’dÏ€câ¢[r]â‰”âˆ’dâ¢(Pâˆ—,PÏ€câ¢[r]),â‰”subscriptâ„›ğ‘Ÿğ‘subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿâ‰”ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{R}_{r,c}\coloneqq-d_{\pi_{c}[r]}\coloneqq-d(P^{*},P_{\pi_{c}[r]})\ ,caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r , italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” - italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” - italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (7)

which is the negated MMD between Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the distribution PÏ€câ¢[r]subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘ŸP_{\pi_{c}[r]}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at the rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-th position of the permutation Ï€csubscriptğœ‹ğ‘\pi_{c}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and hence the payoff matrix â„›â„›\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R is

â„›â‰”[âˆ’dÏ€1â¢[1]âˆ’dÏ€2â¢[1]âˆ’dÏ€3â¢[1]â€¦âˆ’dÏ€n!â¢[1]âˆ’dÏ€1â¢[2]âˆ’dÏ€2â¢[2]âˆ’dÏ€3â¢[3]â€¦âˆ’dÏ€n!â¢[3]â‹®â‹®â‹®â‹±â‹®âˆ’dÏ€1â¢[n]âˆ’dÏ€2â¢[n]âˆ’dÏ€3â¢[n]â€¦âˆ’dÏ€n!â¢[n]].â‰”â„›matrixsubscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹1delimited-[]1subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹2delimited-[]1subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹3delimited-[]1â€¦subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘›delimited-[]1subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹1delimited-[]2subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹2delimited-[]2subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹3delimited-[]3â€¦subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘›delimited-[]3â‹®â‹®â‹®â‹±â‹®subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹1delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹2delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹3delimited-[]ğ‘›â€¦subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘›delimited-[]ğ‘›\mathcal{R}\coloneqq\begin{bmatrix}-d_{\pi_{1}[1]}&-d_{\pi_{2}[1]}&-d_{\pi_{3}% [1]}&\dots&-d_{\pi_{n!}[1]}\\ -d_{\pi_{1}[2]}&-d_{\pi_{2}[2]}&-d_{\pi_{3}[3]}&\dots&-d_{\pi_{n!}[3]}\\ \vdots&\vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ -d_{\pi_{1}[n]}&-d_{\pi_{2}[n]}&-d_{\pi_{3}[n]}&\dots&-d_{\pi_{n!}[n]}\end{% bmatrix}.caligraphic_R â‰” [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL - italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL - italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL - italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL â€¦ end_CELL start_CELL - italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ! end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

The notation rğ‘Ÿritalic_r is used specifically refer to the position in a permutation Ï€csubscriptğœ‹ğ‘\pi_{c}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and is not to be confused with indexing iğ‘–iitalic_i of the data vendors. For completeness, the payoff matrix ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C of the column player is the negation of â„›â„›\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R (i.e., â„›+ğ’=ğŸâ„›ğ’0\mathcal{R}+\mathcal{C}=\mathbf{0}caligraphic_R + caligraphic_C = bold_0). Observe that this is a finite, two-player zero-sum game.

3: The uniform strategy is worst-case optimal.

While the values of the entries in â„›â„›\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R are not known explicitly, there are some properties of these values that can be exploited. We provide a constructive proof: formulate the primal and dual linear programsÂ (LPs) for the two-player game as in Eq.Â 4, show that the uniform strategies lead to equal values for both LPs, and conclude that, by the strong duality, both are optimal.

Proof of 3.

For the row player, the optimal strategy srowâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ rows^{*}_{\text{row}}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT row end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be computed via the following LPÂ (1)Â [18], the value of which is equal to the row playerâ€™s payoff based on the column playerâ€™s optimal response scolâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ cols^{*}_{\text{col}}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT col end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to srowâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ rows^{*}_{\text{row}}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT row end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

maxzs.t.Â â¢srowâŠ¤â¢â„›â‰½zâ¢ğŸâŠ¤srowâŠ¤â¢ğŸ=1srowâ‰½ğŸ.succeeds-or-equalsğ‘§s.t.Â superscriptsubscriptğ‘ rowtopâ„›ğ‘§superscript1topsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ rowtop11subscriptğ‘ rowsucceeds-or-equals0\displaystyle\begin{split}\max~{}&z\\ \text{s.t.~{}}s_{\text{row}}^{\top}\mathcal{R}&\succcurlyeq z\mathbf{1}^{\top}% \\ s_{\text{row}}^{\top}\mathbf{1}&=1\\ s_{\text{row}}&\succcurlyeq\mathbf{0}\ .\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL roman_max end_CELL start_CELL italic_z end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL s.t. italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT row end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_CELL start_CELL â‰½ italic_z bold_1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT row end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_1 end_CELL start_CELL = 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT row end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL â‰½ bold_0 . end_CELL end_ROW LPÂ (1)

Observe that LPÂ (3) is the LP for the column player to solve for scolâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ cols^{*}_{\text{col}}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT col end_POSTSUBSCRIPTÂ [18].

Our proof has the main following steps:

  1. 1.

    Verify that the uniform strategy [1/n,1/n,â€¦,1/n]1ğ‘›1ğ‘›â€¦1ğ‘›[1/n,1/n,\ldots,1/n][ 1 / italic_n , 1 / italic_n , â€¦ , 1 / italic_n ] is a feasible solution to LPÂ (1) and obtain the corresponding value zğ‘§zitalic_z.

  2. 2.

    Verify that the uniform strategy [1/(n!),1/(n!),â€¦,1/(n!)]1ğ‘›1ğ‘›â€¦1ğ‘›[1/(n!),1/(n!),\ldots,1/(n!)][ 1 / ( italic_n ! ) , 1 / ( italic_n ! ) , â€¦ , 1 / ( italic_n ! ) ] is a feasible solution to LPÂ (3), obtain the corresponding value zâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘§â€²â€²z^{\prime\prime}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and translate to the value zâ€²=âˆ’zâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘§â€²superscriptğ‘§â€²â€²z^{\prime}=-z^{\prime\prime}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = - italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to LPÂ (2).

  3. 3.

    Apply the strong duality: If the values of the primal and dual LPs are equal (i.e., z=zâ€²ğ‘§superscriptğ‘§â€²z=z^{\prime}italic_z = italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), then the corresponding solutions must both be optimal.

For step 1., we make use of a key observation that the set ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G of distributions is fixed, which implies that independent of the permutations Ï€csubscriptğœ‹ğ‘\pi_{c}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the sum Sâ‰”âˆ‘r=1nâˆ’dâ¢(Ï€câ¢[r])â‰”ğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘ŸS\coloneqq\sum_{r=1}^{n}-d(\pi_{c}[r])italic_S â‰” âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_d ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] ) is thus a constant. Then, for any Ï€csubscriptğœ‹ğ‘\pi_{c}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it gives the zÏ€c=Snsubscriptğ‘§subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘›z_{\pi_{c}}=\frac{S}{n}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARGÂ , so the overall value is zâ‰”mincâ¡zÏ€c=S/nâ‰”ğ‘§subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘§subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘›z\coloneqq\min_{c}z_{\pi_{c}}=S/nitalic_z â‰” roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_S / italic_nÂ .

For step 2., in the rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-th row of ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C:

[dÏ€1â¢[r],dÏ€2â¢[r],â€¦,dÏ€n!â¢[r]],subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹1delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹2delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿâ€¦subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘›delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿ[d_{\pi_{1}[r]},d_{\pi_{2}[r]},\ldots,d_{\pi_{n!}[r]}]\ ,[ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ! end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ,

there are (nâˆ’1)!ğ‘›1(n-1)!( italic_n - 1 ) ! entries/copies of each di,1â‰¤iâ‰¤nsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘›d_{i},1\leq i\leq nitalic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 â‰¤ italic_i â‰¤ italic_n. This is because out of n!ğ‘›n!italic_n ! possible permutations, any particular iğ‘–iitalic_i appears at the rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-th position exactly (nâˆ’1)!ğ‘›1(n-1)!( italic_n - 1 ) ! times (since there are (nâˆ’1)!ğ‘›1(n-1)!( italic_n - 1 ) ! permutations of the others). Hence, the value corresponding to the uniform strategy [1/(n!),1/(n!),â€¦,1/(n!)]1ğ‘›1ğ‘›â€¦1ğ‘›[1/(n!),1/(n!),\ldots,1/(n!)][ 1 / ( italic_n ! ) , 1 / ( italic_n ! ) , â€¦ , 1 / ( italic_n ! ) ] for the rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-th row in ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C is

zrâ€²â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘§â€²â€²ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle z^{\prime\prime}_{r}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =âˆ‘c=1n!1n!â¢dÏ€câ¢[r]absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ‘›1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle=\sum_{c=1}^{n!}\frac{1}{n!}d_{\pi_{c}[r]}= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ! end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n ! end_ARG italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
=1n!â¢âˆ‘c=1n!dÏ€câ¢[r]absent1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle=\frac{1}{n!}\sum_{c=1}^{n!}d_{\pi_{c}[r]}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n ! end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ! end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
