=(nâˆ’1)!n!â¢âˆ‘i=1nd[i]absentğ‘›1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘delimited-[]ğ‘–\displaystyle=\frac{(n-1)!}{n!}\sum_{i=1}^{n}d_{[i]}= divide start_ARG ( italic_n - 1 ) ! end_ARG start_ARG italic_n ! end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_i ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
=âˆ’1nâ¢S.absent1ğ‘›ğ‘†\displaystyle=-\frac{1}{n}S\ .= - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG italic_S .

The third equality applies the above argument of any iğ‘–iitalic_i appearing at the rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-th position exactly (nâˆ’1)!ğ‘›1(n-1)!( italic_n - 1 ) ! times. Since this is true for any rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-th row and that it does not explicitly depend on rğ‘Ÿritalic_r, the overall value zâ€²â€²â‰”maxrâ¡zrâ€²â€²=âˆ’Sn.â‰”superscriptğ‘§â€²â€²subscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘§â€²â€²ğ‘Ÿğ‘†ğ‘›z^{\prime\prime}\coloneqq\max_{r}z^{\prime\prime}_{r}=-\frac{S}{n}\ .italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - divide start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG . Then, the corresponding solution to LPÂ (2) has zâ€²=âˆ’zâ€²â€²=1nâ¢S.superscriptğ‘§â€²superscriptğ‘§â€²â€²1ğ‘›ğ‘†z^{\prime}=-z^{\prime\prime}=\frac{1}{n}S\ .italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = - italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG italic_S .

For step 3., apply the strong duality (since z=zâ€²=S/nğ‘§superscriptğ‘§â€²ğ‘†ğ‘›z=z^{\prime}=S/nitalic_z = italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_S / italic_n) and conclude that the uniform strategies are optimal for both the row and column players. âˆ

3 implies that the uniform strategy is the worst-case optimal approach when selecting a data vendor at the rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-th position (whose distribution to use as the reference) without any prior knowledge or assumptions about the data vendors (i.e., regardless of how the data vendors are ordered).555By the classic [60, Minmax Theorem], these minmax solutions for both players form a Nash equilibrium.

Uniform mixture PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the uniform strategy.

Since the uniform strategy is worst-case optimal, we implement it via the uniform mixture of the data vendorsâ€™ distributions PUâ‰”1nâ¢âˆ‘iPi,â‰”subscriptğ‘ƒU1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{\text{U}}\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}P_{i}\ ,italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , as the proposed reference in place of Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to define Eq.Â 3 as a practically tractable approximation to Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ (which itself cannot be used since Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is unknown). In particular, the results on bounded approximation error and actionable policy derived w.r.t.Â a general PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., 2 and TheoremÂ 1) is applicable to PÏ‰=PUsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”subscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\omega}=P_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT since PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a special case of PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as the following corollaries.

Corollary 1.

Let Î¥^â‰”âˆ’dâ¢(P,PU),â‰”^Î¥ğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒU\hat{\Upsilon}\coloneqq-d(P,P_{\text{U}}),over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG â‰” - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , then âˆ€Pfor-allğ‘ƒ\forall Pâˆ€ italic_P, |Î¥â¢(P)âˆ’Î¥^â¢(P)|â‰¤ÎµUâ¢dâ¢(Pâˆ—,QU).Î¥ğ‘ƒ^Î¥ğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ€Uğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘„U|\Upsilon(P)-\hat{\Upsilon}(P)|\leq\varepsilon_{\text{U}}d(P^{*},Q_{\text{U}})\ .| roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) - over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG ( italic_P ) | â‰¤ italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

Proof of CorollaryÂ 1.

The result follows by directly applying 2 with ÎµU,QUsubscriptğœ€Usubscriptğ‘„U\varepsilon_{\text{U}},Q_{\text{U}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPTÂ . âˆ

Corollary 2.

Given datasets Dâˆ¼Psimilar-toğ·ğ‘ƒD\sim Pitalic_D âˆ¼ italic_P and Dâ€²âˆ¼Pâ€²similar-tosuperscriptğ·â€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²D^{\prime}\sim P^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, let mâ‰”|D|â‰”ğ‘šğ·m\coloneqq|D|italic_m â‰” | italic_D | and mâ€²â‰”|Dâ€²|â‰”superscriptğ‘šâ€²superscriptğ·â€²m^{\prime}\coloneqq|D^{\prime}|italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” | italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT |. Let Î½^^ğœˆ\hat{\nu}over^ start_ARG italic_Î½ end_ARG be from Eq.Â 3 where DÏ‰subscriptğ·ğœ”D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is specified as DUsubscriptğ·UD_{\text{U}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: Î½^â¢(D)â‰”âˆ’d^â¢(D,DU)â‰”^ğœˆğ·^ğ‘‘ğ·subscriptğ·U\hat{\nu}(D)\coloneqq-\hat{d}(D,D_{\text{U}})over^ start_ARG italic_Î½ end_ARG ( italic_D ) â‰” - over^ start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and mNâ‰”|DU|â‰”subscriptğ‘šğ‘subscriptğ·Um_{N}\coloneqq|D_{\text{U}}|italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” | italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |. For some bias requirement Îµbiasâ‰¥0subscriptğœ€bias0\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}\geq 0italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 and a required decision margin ÎµÎ¥â‰¥0subscriptğœ€Î¥0\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}\geq 0italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0, suppose Î½^â¢(D)>Î½^â¢(Dâ€²)+Î”Î¥,Î½â€²^ğœˆğ·^ğœˆsuperscriptğ·â€²subscriptsuperscriptÎ”â€²Î¥ğœˆ\hat{\nu}(D)>\hat{\nu}(D^{\prime})+\Delta^{\prime}_{\Upsilon,\nu}over^ start_ARG italic_Î½ end_ARG ( italic_D ) > over^ start_ARG italic_Î½ end_ARG ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ , italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where the criterion margin Î”Î¥,Î½â€²â‰”ÎµÎ¥+2â¢[Îµbias+K/m+K/mâ€²+2â¢K/mN+ÎµUâ¢dâ¢(QU,Pâˆ—)]â‰”subscriptsuperscriptÎ”â€²Î¥ğœˆsubscriptğœ€Î¥2delimited-[]subscriptğœ€biasğ¾ğ‘šğ¾superscriptğ‘šâ€²2ğ¾subscriptğ‘šğ‘subscriptğœ€Uğ‘‘subscriptğ‘„Usuperscriptğ‘ƒ\Delta^{\prime}_{\Upsilon,\nu}\coloneqq\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}+2\boldsymbol{[}% \varepsilon_{\text{bias}}+\sqrt{{K}/{m}}+\sqrt{{K}/{m^{\prime}}}+2\sqrt{{K}/{m% _{N}}}+\varepsilon_{\text{U}}d(Q_{\text{U}},P^{*})\boldsymbol{]}\ roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ , italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 bold_[ italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + square-root start_ARG italic_K / italic_m end_ARG + square-root start_ARG italic_K / italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + 2 square-root start_ARG italic_K / italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) bold_]. Let Î´â€²â‰”2â¢expâ¡(âˆ’Îµbias2â¢mÂ¯â¢mN2â¢Kâ¢(mÂ¯+mN))â‰”superscriptğ›¿â€²2superscriptsubscriptğœ€bias2Â¯ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘šğ‘2ğ¾Â¯ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘šğ‘\delta^{\prime}\coloneqq 2\exp(\frac{-\varepsilon_{\text{bias}}^{2}\overline{m% }m_{N}}{2K(\overline{m}+m_{N})})italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” 2 roman_exp ( divide start_ARG - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bias end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_m end_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_m end_ARG + italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) where mÂ¯=maxâ¡{m,mâ€²}Â¯ğ‘šğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘šâ€²\overline{m}=\max\{m,m^{\prime}\}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_m end_ARG = roman_max { italic_m , italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }. Then Î¥â¢(P)>Î¥â¢(Pâ€²)+ÎµÎ¥Î¥ğ‘ƒÎ¥superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²subscriptğœ€Î¥\Upsilon(P)>\Upsilon(P^{\prime})+\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) > roman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with probability at least (1âˆ’2â¢Î´â€²)12superscriptğ›¿â€²(1-2\delta^{\prime})( 1 - 2 italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Proof of CorollaryÂ 2.

The result follows by directly applying TheoremÂ 1 with DU,ÎµU,QUsubscriptğ·Usubscriptğœ€Usubscriptğ‘„UD_{\text{U}},\varepsilon_{\text{U}},Q_{\text{U}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPTÂ . âˆ

Difficulties of searching over all convex mixtures Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰.

Note that the game specified in Eq.Â 4 has a finite action space Nğ‘Nitalic_N for the row player. Essentially, it means that the row player is considering exactly one of the nğ‘›nitalic_n data vendors as the reference, though the minmax solution suggests that the row player should adopt a mixed strategy to consider all nğ‘›nitalic_n data vendors equally.

A natural extension of the game is for the row player to consider all possible convex mixtures Ï‰âˆˆâ–³â¢(nâˆ’1)ğœ”â–³ğ‘›1\omega\in\triangle(n-1)italic_Ï‰ âˆˆ â–³ ( italic_n - 1 ):

maxÏ‰âˆˆâ–³â¢(nâˆ’1)â¡minÏ€âˆˆÎ â¢(N)âˆ’dâ¢(Pâˆ—,PÏ‰,Ï€)subscriptğœ”â–³ğ‘›1subscriptğœ‹Î ğ‘ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğœ‹\max_{\omega\in\triangle(n-1)}\min_{\pi\in\Pi(N)}-d(P^{*},P_{\omega,\pi})roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ âˆˆ â–³ ( italic_n - 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ âˆˆ roman_Î  ( italic_N ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ , italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (8)

where PÏ‰,Ï€â‰”âˆ‘r=1nPÏ€â¢[r]â¢Ï‰r,â‰”subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğœ‹superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ƒğœ‹delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğœ”ğ‘ŸP_{\omega,\pi}\coloneqq\sum_{r=1}^{n}P_{\pi[r]}\omega_{r}\ ,italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ , italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , is a mixture specified by Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ following the permutation Ï€,ğœ‹\pi\ ,italic_Ï€ , and Î â¢(n)Î ğ‘›\Pi(n)roman_Î  ( italic_n ) denotes the set of all possible permutations of {1,2,â€¦,n}.12â€¦ğ‘›\{1,2,\ldots,n\}\ .{ 1 , 2 , â€¦ , italic_n } .

From a theoretical perspective (i.e., to understand and analyze the optimal solution, if one exists, to Eq.Â 8), there are some difficulties because Eq.Â 8 is an infinite game (because of the action space of the row player). In particular, infinite games (or semi-finite games where one player has a finite action space) are significantly harder to analyze the optimality or even existence of the (optimal) solution. In general, it is not guaranteed that the optimal solution(s) exist for one or both of the playersÂ [61], and in cases where the optimal solutions exist, there may be a so-called duality gapÂ [21]: The minimax theorem for the finite game implies that the optimal solutions for both players will give values that coincide (i.e., the optimal for row player is the negated optimal for the column player), but the duality gap means that in the infinite regime, the optimal solutions may not give values that coincide, making it harder to even verify if a pair of solutions is optimal (since the values may not coincide even if they are indeed optimal).

Moreover, the MMD dğ‘‘ditalic_d in Eq.Â 8 introduces an additional difficulty since it is not guaranteed to be convex in the mixture of the models: for some Î»âˆˆ[0,1],P1,P2ğœ†01subscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2\lambda\in[0,1],P_{1},P_{2}italic_Î» âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the convex combination of Î»â¢dâ¢(Pâˆ—,P1)+(1âˆ’Î»)â¢dâ¢(Pâˆ—,P2)ğœ†ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒ11ğœ†ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒ2\lambda d(P^{*},P_{1})+(1-\lambda)d(P^{*},P_{2})italic_Î» italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ( 1 - italic_Î» ) italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is not necessarily smaller than or equal to dâ¢(Pâˆ—,Î»â¢P1+(1âˆ’Î»)â¢P2)ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒğœ†subscriptğ‘ƒ11ğœ†subscriptğ‘ƒ2d(P^{*},\lambda P_{1}+(1-\lambda)P_{2})italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Î» italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_Î» ) italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). In other words, there are cases where either direction of the inequality is true. The implication is that, when searching or optimizing over Ï‰âˆˆâ–³â¢(nâˆ’1)ğœ”â–³ğ‘›1\omega\in\triangle(n-1)italic_Ï‰ âˆˆ â–³ ( italic_n - 1 ) via methods that try to â€œmoveâ€ a current solution by a small amount to arrive at a new solution (or towards the optimum), it is more difficult to do so, since moving the current solution might increase or decrease the value (and it is not known a priori which).

A.4.3 Additional Discussion on Approximation Error

The result on the approximation error (i.e., 2) can be useful in designing alternative approaches of finding a reference, and also in considering additional desiderata (e.g., incentive compatibilityÂ [5] and truthfulnessÂ [14]).

Precisely, for any Prefsubscriptğ‘ƒrefP_{\text{ref}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (e.g., PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), if it is boundedly close to Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the MMD sense, then a bounded approximation error is available (by the triangle inequality of MMD):

dâ¢(Pref,Pâˆ—)â‰¤ÎµrefâŸ¹âˆ€P,|Î¥â¢(P)âˆ’Î¥~refâ¢(P)|â‰¤Îµrefformulae-sequenceğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒrefsuperscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ€reffor-allğ‘ƒÎ¥ğ‘ƒsubscript~Î¥refğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ€refd(P_{\text{ref}},P^{*})\leq\varepsilon_{\text{ref}}\implies\forall P,|\Upsilon% (P)-\tilde{\Upsilon}_{\text{ref}}(P)|\leq\varepsilon_{\text{ref}}italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¹ âˆ€ italic_P , | roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) - over~ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P ) | â‰¤ italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (9)

where Î¥~refâ¢(P)â‰”âˆ’dâ¢(P,Pref)â‰”subscript~Î¥refğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒref\tilde{\Upsilon}_{\text{ref}}(P)\coloneqq-d(P,P_{\text{ref}})over~ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P ) â‰” - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). We highlight that this precise formalization and the subsequent discussion have not been presented in related existing works (e.g., [1, 14, 59, 65]), and that this discussion is enabled by the analytic properties of Huber and MMD.

A possible optimization approach for finding a reference and its difficulties.

Intuitively, a smaller approximation error is more desirable (and later we will discuss a specific such desideratum), so naturally we want to minimize it. The following objective is such an example, to be optimized/minimized over all possible convex mixtures of the data vendorsâ€™ distributions:

minÏ‰âˆˆâ–³â¢(nâˆ’1)â¢supP|âˆ’dâ¢(P,Pâˆ—)âˆ’(âˆ’dâ¢(P,PÏ‰))|subscriptğœ”â–³ğ‘›1subscriptsupremumğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”\min_{\omega\in\triangle(n-1)}\sup_{P}|-d(P,P^{*})-(-d(P,P_{\omega}))|roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ âˆˆ â–³ ( italic_n - 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - ( - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) | (10)

where PÏ‰â‰”âˆ‘iÏ‰iâ¢Piâ‰”subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”subscriptğ‘–subscriptğœ”ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{\omega}\coloneqq\sum_{i}\omega_{i}P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a convex mixture of the data vendorsâ€™ distributions as in 1. The triangle inequality of MMD enables a simplification of Eq.Â 10 to the minimization of an upper bound (of the original objective) instead:

minÏ‰âˆˆâ–³â¢(nâˆ’1)â¡dâ¢(PÏ‰,Pâˆ—).subscriptğœ”â–³ğ‘›1ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒ\min_{\omega\in\triangle(n-1)}d(P_{\omega},P^{*})\ .roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ âˆˆ â–³ ( italic_n - 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

From an implementation or practical perspective, this objective, unfortunately, presents a major practical difficulty in that Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not available (which is the reason for obtaining a reference in the first place). Hence, additional assumptions are required to make this objective tractable (e.g., a validation dataset from Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is available [24, 39, 62], each Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is assumed to be somewhat â€œcloseâ€ to Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [1, 14] or the union or some combination of {Pi}iâˆˆNsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘\{P_{i}\}_{i\in N}{ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [59, 65]).

We highlight that the assumption Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is available is indeed a key challenge that we aim to address (by relaxing this assumption) because in practice Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not available. Hence, exploring a suitable form of the assumption (in the sense that it is practically feasible and also enables a tractable optimization of Eq.Â 10) presents an interesting future direction.

Additional desiderata.

We make precise the intuition that a smaller approximation error is more desirable by connecting the approximation error to the so-called incentive compatibility (IC), frequently used in (truthful) mechanism designsÂ [5, 6, 8, 14]).

Definition 2 (Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³-incentive compatibility).

The valuation function Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ is Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³-incentive compatible, for some Î³â‰¥0ğ›¾0\gamma\geq 0italic_Î³ â‰¥ 0, if

Î¥â¢(Pi;{Piâ€²}iâ€²âˆˆNâˆ–{i},â‹…)â‰¥Î¥â¢(P~i;{Piâ€²}iâ€²âˆˆNâˆ–{i},â‹…)âˆ’Î³Î¥subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘–â€²superscriptğ‘–â€²ğ‘ğ‘–â‹…Î¥subscript~ğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘–â€²superscriptğ‘–â€²ğ‘ğ‘–â‹…ğ›¾\Upsilon(P_{i};\{P_{i^{\prime}}\}_{i^{\prime}\in N\setminus\{i\}},\cdot)\geq% \Upsilon(\tilde{P}_{i};\{P_{i^{\prime}}\}_{i^{\prime}\in N\setminus\{i\}},% \cdot)-\gammaroman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; { italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_N âˆ– { italic_i } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹… ) â‰¥ roman_Î¥ ( over~ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; { italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_N âˆ– { italic_i } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹… ) - italic_Î³

where P~isubscript~ğ‘ƒğ‘–\tilde{P}_{i}over~ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the mis-reported version of Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.666An example of mis-reporting is injecting artificial noise.

In DefinitionÂ 2Â [6, 5], Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0italic_Î³ = 0 recovers the exact definition of IC. IC is an important desideratum in that it can be used to show that each vendor being truthful (i.e., not misreporting) forms an equilibriumÂ [14] and truthfulness is another such desideratum.

Depending on the specific design, the valuation Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ can have different additional dependencies. For instance, in the ideal case where Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is available, Î¥â¢(P)â‰”âˆ’dâ¢(P,Pâˆ—)â‰”Î¥ğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒ\Upsilon(P)\coloneqq-d(P,P^{*})roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) â‰” - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) has an explicit dependence on Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and it satisfies Î³dÂ¯subscriptğ›¾Â¯ğ‘‘\gamma_{\bar{d}}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_d end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-IC where dÂ¯â‰”maxiâ¡dâ¢(Pi,Pâˆ—)â‰”Â¯ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒ\bar{d}\coloneqq\max_{i}d(P_{i},P^{*})overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_d end_ARG â‰” roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (can be directly verified using DefinitionÂ 2). On the other hand, for some Î¥^â¢(P)â‰”âˆ’dâ¢(P,Pref)â‰”^Î¥ğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒref\hat{\Upsilon}(P)\coloneqq-d(P,P_{\text{ref}})over^ start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG ( italic_P ) â‰” - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) s.t.Â dâ¢(Pref,Pâˆ—)=Îµrefğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒrefsuperscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ€refd(P_{\text{ref}},P^{*})=\varepsilon_{\text{ref}}italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it has a weaker IC (i.e., a larger corresponding Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³): it satisfies Î³refsubscriptğ›¾ref\gamma_{\text{ref}}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-IC for Î³refâ‰”Îµref+dÂ¯â‰”subscriptğ›¾refsubscriptğœ€refÂ¯ğ‘‘\gamma_{\text{ref}}\coloneqq\varepsilon_{\text{ref}}+\bar{d}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_d end_ARG, by the triangle inequality of MMD. Notice that Îµrefsubscriptğœ€ref\varepsilon_{\text{ref}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is directly related to the approximation error above, so this suggests that analyzing and then minimizing the approximation error to design a solution with strong IC is a promising future direction. Indeed, some preliminary empirical results (Sec.Â D.3.5) demonstrate some promise that (approximate) IC is achievable in some cases.

Note that even in the ideal case where Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is available, the exact IC is not necessarily guaranteed. This is because the (truthfully reported) distribution Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by each vendor iğ‘–iitalic_i is not guaranteed to be the same as Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is often the case in practice where the data collected are not guaranteed to be directly from the ground truth distributionÂ [24, 32, 57]. Hence, it is theoretically possible that a â€œmis-reportedâ€ P~isubscript~ğ‘ƒğ‘–\tilde{P}_{i}over~ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is such that dâ¢(P~i,Pâˆ—)<dâ¢(Pi,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘subscript~ğ‘ƒğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒd(\tilde{P}_{i},P^{*})<d(P_{i},P^{*})italic_d ( over~ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), namely an improvement from Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, such cases would be rare in practice since it is generally difficult to â€œmoveâ€ a distribution Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (via some statistical operation) towards an unknown optimal distribution Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as otherwise Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can obtained by simply performing such operations on a given distribution Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT until it reaches Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Moreover, [36, 37, 44] have noted that, in our setting of no reference/ground truth (i.e., no Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), it is impossible design a mechanism that guarantees truthfulness of the data vendors, if the data vendors are not assumed to be completely independent of each other. In other words, without access to ground truth, and if there is possibility of so-called side information among the data vendors themselves, a truthful mechanism is impossible, further highlighting the difficulties of our setting (i.e., without a reference).

Appendix B Additional Discussion on Related Works

B.1 Discussion on the Assumptions of Related Works and Applicability to the Problem Statement

In addition to the existing works mentioned in Sec.Â 2, [7, 31, 32, 70] also share a similar dependence on a given reference dataset. Consequently, it is unclear how to apply these methods without a given reference dataset.

Next, we elaborate the works that relax the assumption of a given reference and better contrast their differences from our work, specifically in how they relax this assumption.

Chen etÂ al. [14, Assumption 3.2] require that Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT must follow a known parametric form and the posterior of the parameters is known. Chen etÂ al. [14] assumes that each data vendor collects data from the ground truth data distribution (parametrized by some unknown parameters) and performs the analysis on whether a data vendor iğ‘–iitalic_i will report untruthfully when everyone else is reporting truthfully. Specifically, the reference is the aggregate of all vendors excluding the vendor iğ‘–iitalic_i itself. It is unclear how heterogeneity can be formalized in their theoretical analysis, which assumes the vendors are collecting data from the same (ground truth) data distribution. [59] directly assumes that the aggregate dataset DÏ‰subscriptğ·ğœ”D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or the aggregate distribution PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a sufficiently good representation of Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and thus provides a good reference, without formally justifying it or accounting for the cause or effect of heterogeneity. Wei etÂ al. [65, Assumption 3.1] require that for any i,iâ€²ğ‘–superscriptğ‘–â€²i,i^{\prime}italic_i , italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the densities of Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Piâ€²subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘–â€²P_{i^{\prime}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT must lie on the same support, which is difficult to guarantee because Qi,Qiâ€²subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–subscriptğ‘„superscriptğ‘–â€²Q_{i},Q_{i^{\prime}}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can have different supports (resulting in Pi,Piâ€²subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘–â€²P_{i},P_{i^{\prime}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT having different supports). [65] uses the fğ‘“fitalic_f-divergence specifically the KL divergence, which requires an assumption that the densities of the data distributions (of all the vendors) to lie on the same support [65, Assumption 3.1]. This assumption can be difficult to satisfy in practice since the analytic expression of the density of the data distribution is often complex and unknown. To illustrate, our experiments consider heterogeneity in the form of mixture between MNIST and FaMNIST; it is unclear how to satisfy the assumption that the densities of the distributions of MNIST and FAMNIST lie on the same support. Moreover, their method does not formally model heterogeneity or its effect on the value of data.

Furthermore, a similarity in these works [14, 59, 65] is how they leverage the â€œmajorityâ€ to construct a reference either implicitly or explicitly. Specifically, in [14], the reference for vendor iğ‘–iitalic_i is the aggregate of every vendorâ€™s dataset except iğ‘–iitalic_i; in [59, 65] the reference is constructed by utilizing both the aggregate dataset DÏ‰subscriptğ·ğœ”D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and additionally some synthetically generated data (Tay etÂ al. [59] use the MMD-GAN while Wei etÂ al. [65] use the fğ‘“fitalic_f-divergence GAN). We highlight that these works did not provide a theoretical analysis on â€œhow goodâ€ their respective reference is, namely, what is the error from using the reference instead of using the ground truth? In contrast, we answer this question via 2 and propose to use the uniformly weighted â€œmajorityâ€ as the solution, inspired by the worst-case optimality of the uniform strategy in the two-player zero-sum game (3).

B.2 Comparison with Alternative Distances/Divergences

Supplementing the comparison of TableÂ 1, we provide additional details and discussion with alternative distances/divergences (to our adopted MMD) that have already been adopted for the purpose of data valuation.

Comparison between Ours and MMD2.

Empirically, ours (i.e., MMD-based) and MMD2 [59] perform similarly across the investigated settings (including empirical convergence and ranking data distributions), which is unsurprising since theoretically the numerical values only differ by a square. Although MMD2 has an unbiased estimator [26, Eq.Â (4)] while MMD, to our knowledge, only has a biased estimator [26, Eq.Â (6)], this advantage does not seem significant, since the convergence results in Sec.Â 5.1 demonstrate similar convergences for Ours and MMD2. Recall that Sec.Â 5, we highlighted that the implemented estimator for MMD2 is not obtained from taking the square of that for MMD. Nevertheless, we have also tried this implementation of directly squaring the estimator for MMD to be the estimator of MMD2 but did not observe a significant difference in the empirical results.

On the other hand, from a theoretical perspective, the difference in terms of the implications, is more significant. This is primarily due to the analytic properties of MMD, which are not also satisfied by MMD2, such as the triangle inequality, used to derive 2, and the property with Huber model (i.e., Eq.Â 2) which is used to derive LemmaÂ 4 and TheoremÂ 1. It is an interesting future direction to explore similar results for MMD2.

Comparison between Ours and the Wasserstein metric.

Similar to MMD, the Wasserstein metric, also known as the optimal transport (OT) distance [34] also satisfies the axioms of a metric, in particular the triangle inequality. This can make the Wasserstein metric a promising choice for our setting. However, MMD seems to have two important advantages â€”one theoretical and the other practicalâ€”: (i) Under the Huber model, MMD enables a simple and direct relationship (i.e., Eq.Â 2) that precisely characterizes how the heterogeneity (formalized by Huber) of a distribution affects its value. It is unclear how or whether the Wasserstein metric can provide the same relationship, and some works [50, 51] seem to suggest the difficulties of obtaining the same relationship. (ii) The definition of the Wasserstein metric (involving taking an infimum over the couplings of distributions) makes its value difficult to obtain (compute or approximate) in practice. Indeed, LAVAâ€™s official implementation [33, Github repo] does not directly compute/approximate the 2-Wasserstein distance, but instead obtains the calibrated gradients as a surrogate [33, Sec.Â 3.2], which are not explicitly guaranteed to approximate the 2-Wasserstein-based values. In contrast, our method directly approximates the MMD (with the estimator [26, Eq.Â (6)]) with a clear theoretical guarantee (LemmaÂ 1). In other words, though the Wasserstein metric satisfies the appealing theoretical properties, in implementation, a valuation based on the Wasserstein metric is difficult to obtain directly, and instead some surrogate is obtained. Moreover, it has not yet been guaranteed that this surrogate also satisfies (possibly approximately) the same appealing theoretical properties that might make the Wasserstein metric a promising choice.

Comparison between Ours and fğ‘“fitalic_f-divergences.

The fğ‘“fitalic_f-divergences family presents a rich choice (since it contains many specific divergences such as Kullback-Leibler, total variation and etc.) and is also adopted in existing works such as [14, Definition 4.5], [65, Algorithm 1] and [1, Eq.(1)] for the theoretical properties of the adopted fğ‘“fitalic_f-divergence (or variant). For instance, the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence satisfies the required [65, Assumption 3.4] for the proposed method, while the extended KL divergence proposed by Agussurja etÂ al. [1, Sec.Â 3] enables a decomposition of the terms to simplify the analysis.

These theoretical properties notwithstanding, our adopted MMD has a clear advantage over the fğ‘“fitalic_f-divergence with important practical implications. A commonly made assumption with using the fğ‘“fitalic_f-divergence fâ¢(Pâˆ¥Q)ğ‘“conditionalğ‘ƒğ‘„f(P\|Q)italic_f ( italic_P âˆ¥ italic_Q ) is the absolute continuity of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P w.r.t.Â Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q, since otherwise the division-by-zero makes the definition ill-behaved. This assumption is difficult to satisfy or even verify in practice, especially for complex and high-dimensional data distributions. In contrast, the sample-based definition of MMD does not require such an assumption, making its application to complex and high-dimensional data distributions easier (in the sense that the user does not have to worry about a difficult-to-satisfy assumption). Intuitively, this difference between fğ‘“fitalic_f-divergences and most integral probability metrics (IPMs) such as MMD, is that when Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q have disjoint supports, all fğ‘“fitalic_f-divergences take on a constant value; in contrast, IPMs can give â€œpartial creditâ€.

Another important practical implication due to the difference in the definitions of fğ‘“fitalic_f-divergences and MMD is that: it is more direct and easier to approximate MMD (e.g., using a sample-based approach [26, Eq.Â (6)] and with a theoretical guarantee as in LemmaÂ 1). In contrast, the definition of the fğ‘“fitalic_f-divergence fâ¢(Pâˆ¥Q)ğ‘“conditionalğ‘ƒğ‘„f(P\|Q)italic_f ( italic_P âˆ¥ italic_Q ) that directly depends on the density functions of P,Qğ‘ƒğ‘„P,Qitalic_P , italic_Q adds to the difficulties of estimating it in practice, as it requires estimating the density functions (or at least the ratio of the density functions). This is difficult for complex and high-dimensional data distributions and may require simplifying assumptions of the parametric form of the distributions (e.g., P,Qğ‘ƒğ‘„P,Qitalic_P , italic_Q are both multi-variate Gaussian [1] to enable a closed-form expression for KL).

B.3 Comparison with other Characterization/Treatment of Data Heterogeneity

As an additional comparison to supplement our remarks in Sec.Â 3 for why adopting the Huber model, we highlight a comparison with relevant existing methods in their treatment of data heterogeneity, and then further elaborate on the analysis based on the design choice of the Huber model.

Recall that the Huber model characterizes a sampling distribution Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P via a mixture (weighted by Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ) between the ground truth distribution Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and some unknown distribution Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q (e.g., an outlier distribution). This characterization is sufficiently general to model several sources of heterogeneity (via Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q) [12, 13], while also having a dependence on the ground truth distribution Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of interest. In our setting, this modeling choice means that the sampling distributions of the different data vendors have varying â€œqualitiesâ€ via their different dependence on the ground truth distribution Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (in pathological cases where Îµâ†’1â†’ğœ€1\varepsilon\to 1italic_Îµ â†’ 1, Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P effectively has no dependence on the ground truth distribution and only contains Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q). This way, Huber model provides a precise yet relatively general way to characterize the differences, namely heterogeneity in the sampling distributions of the data vendors: their sampling distributions may have different dependence on Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and this dependence is made precise via Îµ,Qğœ€ğ‘„\varepsilon,Qitalic_Îµ , italic_Q. This precise characterization is important in enabling the subsequent analysis.

Existing works do not precisely characterize data heterogeneity.

Before highlighting the analysis based on the Huber model and the theoretical appeal thereof, we first compare with some relevant existing works, which either do not characterize the heterogeneity at allÂ [2, 33, 55, 65, 66] , or do so through simplifying assumptionsÂ [1, 14, 59].

Agussurja etÂ al. [1, Assumption (A3)] assume that in the infinite sample regime, for the data from each data vendor, there exists a so-called uniformly consistent distinguisher. In other words, it means, for the purpose of parametric estimation (which is the setting in [1]), the sampling distribution of each vendor has the same quality, this is because with sufficient samples, each vendor individually can identify or recover the true parameters. In summary, this assumption simplifies the problem and bypasses heterogeneity by making the sampling distribution of each data vendor the same specifically w.r.t.Â parametric estimation (i.e., these sampling distributions are not the same in general).

Chen etÂ al. [14, Section 3, Assumption 3.1] assume that the dataset of each vendor consists of i.i.d.Â samples conditioned on some common unknown parameters ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸. The authors also note that â€œThis (Assumption 3.1) is definitely not an assumption that would hold for arbitrarily picked parameters ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸ and any datasets.â€ In this way, it is unclear how the heterogeneity of the sampling distribution of each individual data vendor is precisely characterized.

While Tay etÂ al. [59] consider the sampling distributions of the vendors to be heterogeneous, the authors do not precisely define the heterogeneity. As the treatment, Tay etÂ al. [59, Assumption (B)] assume that the aggregate distribution (i.e., the underlying distribution of the union of the samples from all the data vendors) â€œapproximates the true data distribution well.â€ Note that the authors do not precisely define what it means by approximating the true data distribution well, in contrast we provide such an analysis (i.e., 2 for the general class of convex mixtures).

The (appeal of the) analysis based on the Huber model.

We elaborate further on the property (e.g., LemmaÂ 4) and the results (e.g., Eq.Â 2) based on the Huber model.

In our studied setting with multiple data vendors, the mixture model of Huber is particularly useful because a mixture of Huber distributions is also a Huber, whose parameters (i.e., Îµ,Qğœ€ğ‘„\varepsilon,Qitalic_Îµ , italic_Q) can be derived based on the parameters of the component Huber distributions, namely via LemmaÂ 4. This makes Huber particularly appealing for the purpose of theoretical analysis. To elaborate, given a data valuation function (e.g., Eq.Â 1) that is well suited for Huber distributions, we can use this to evaluate the value of the distribution of a single data vendor, or any specified convex mixture of distributions of multiple data vendors (which is useful for the peer-prediction paradigm [14, 59, 65] and adopted in Sec.Â 4).

Subsequently, our designed MMD-based valuation function in Eq.Â 1 exploits the structural property of the Huber model (i.e., it is a mixture) to provide a precise characterization of the effect of such heterogeneity on the value of data, namely Eq.Â 2. In other words, Eq.Â 2 answers the question: â€œprecisely how does the heterogeneity of a data distribution affect its value?â€ This has not been achieved in prior works.

Additionally, the theoretical properties the Huber model (jointly with the MMD-based valuation) admit the results that describe an actionable policy for comparing different sampling distributions (i.e., 1, TheoremÂ 1), and also a game-theoretic perspective that yield the uniform mixture as the worst-case optimal 3. We highlight that such results leverage certain specific mathematical properties such as LemmaÂ 4 and Eq.Â 2.

Connection to robust statistics and a possible error lower bound.

We highlight that mixture models have deep roots in the field of robust statistics [19, 20, 40] where the goal is to estimate some statistics (e.g., mean and covariance) of the ground truth distribution Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Hence, prior results obtained can shed light on our setting, method and results. For instance, [40] prove an information-theoretic lower bound of error for mean estimation using the data collected from the mixture model (between Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and some outlier distribution Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q). In particular, for a sampling distribution Pâ‰”(1âˆ’Îµ)â¢Pâˆ—+Îµâ¢Qâ‰”ğ‘ƒ1ğœ€superscriptğ‘ƒğœ€ğ‘„P\coloneqq(1-\varepsilon)P^{*}+\varepsilon Qitalic_P â‰” ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Îµ italic_Q, the error (of mean estimation) has a lower bound that is at least linear in the proportion Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ of the outlier distribution [40, Observation I.4]. For our setting, this result can suggest that it is impossible to obtain an arbitrarily good reference PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT s.t.Â dâ¢(PÏ‰,Pâˆ—)<ÎµMMDğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ€MMDd(P_{\omega},P^{*})<\varepsilon_{\text{MMD}}italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT MMD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any desired ÎµMMDâ‰¥0subscriptğœ€MMD0\varepsilon_{\text{MMD}}\geq 0italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT MMD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 where the mixture model is as in 1. This can further justify our approach of using a convex mixture PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the reference, which would have an â€œerrorâ€ (i.e., dâ¢(PÏ‰,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒd(P_{\omega},P^{*})italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )) linear in ÎµÏ‰subscriptğœ€ğœ”\varepsilon_{\omega}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., LemmaÂ 4 or CorollaryÂ 1). Note that here a main difference is that we have multiple data vendors. We need to consider a collection of distributions {Pi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{P_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}{ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and outlier distributions {Qi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{Q_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}{ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where in contrast, [20, 40] consider settings with only one outlier distribution Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q. This means that we need to additionally consider how to â€œcombineâ€ these distributions, which we do so via their convex mixtures as in 1).

We outline an informal sketch of this idea and defer the formal treatment to future work, which requires a careful â€œtranslationâ€ between the settings of mean estimation and distribution estimation, see below: The results in [20, 40] are w.r.t.Â the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm of the error for mean estimation. In our setting, the error (i.e., the MMD dâ¢(PÏ‰,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒd(P_{\omega},P^{*})italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )) is w.r.t.Â the RKHS norm (MMD is an RKHS norm [26, Lemma 4]). Note that, for a function fâˆˆâ„‹ğ‘“â„‹f\in\mathcal{H}italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_H in an RKHS â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H}caligraphic_H, its â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm is dominated by its RKHS norm: â€–fâ€–â„“2â‰¤â€–fâ€–â„‹subscriptnormğ‘“subscriptâ„“2subscriptnormğ‘“â„‹\|f\|_{\ell_{2}}\leq\|f\|_{\mathcal{H}}âˆ¥ italic_f âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ âˆ¥ italic_f âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [17, Section 2]. In other words, one can transfer the information theoretic lower bound (e.g., [40, Observation I.4]) to our setting by using the fact that the MMD (which is an RKHS norm) dominates the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm of the error of mean estimation. Informally, since the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT error of mean estimation is lower bounded, and that the RKHS norm is larger than (or equal to) the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm, the RKHS norm (i.e., the MMD between the any reference PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) is also lower bounded, meaning that it is impossible to find an arbitrarily good reference PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Appendix C Questions & Answers

Due to page constraints of the main paper, we provide some additional elaboration to supplement our main paper and without which would not affect the completeness of the treatment in our main paper. We adopt the form of questions and answers for the convenience of the reader.

Q1.

Why is there a need for explicitly considering a valuation method for a data distribution? Why not directly extend existing dataset valuation methods to data distribution valuations?

Answer: In addition to the practical use-cases outlined in Sec.Â 1 which require a value of a data distribution instead of a value for a finite dataset, there are theoretical considerations for the perspective of data distribution valuation, as elaborated next.

Most existing works focus on defining a value Î½â¢(D)ğœˆğ·\nu(D)italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) for a fixed discrete dataset Dğ·Ditalic_D instead of the value Î¥â¢(P)Î¥ğ‘ƒ\Upsilon(P)roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) for the sampling distribution Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P from which each individual data point in Dğ·Ditalic_D is i.i.d.Â sampled. Then, one might think to extend a defined/given dataset valuation Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½ to define a value Î¥â¢(P)Î¥ğ‘ƒ\Upsilon(P)roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P, such as based on the expectation of Î½â¢(D)ğœˆğ·\nu(D)italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) over the randomness of Dğ·Ditalic_D: For some existing/already defined Î½â¢(D)â†¦â„maps-toğœˆğ·â„\nu(D)\mapsto\mathbb{R}\ italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) â†¦ blackboard_R,

Î¥â¢(P)â‰”ğ”¼Dâˆ¼Pâ¢Î½â¢(D).â‰”Î¥ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ·ğ‘ƒğœˆğ·\Upsilon(P)\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{D\sim P}\nu(D)\ .roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) â‰” blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D âˆ¼ italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) . (11)

Additionally, to account for the fact that Dğ·Ditalic_D has a finite size, consider the limit of this expectation as the size |D|ğ·|D|| italic_D | of Dğ·Ditalic_D approaches infinity, since in the infinite sample regime, the sample statistic obtained on Dğ·Ditalic_D would tend to the population statistic on Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P:

Î¥â¢(P)â‰”lim|D|â†’âˆğ”¼Dâˆ¼Pâ¢Î½â¢(D).â‰”Î¥ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ†’ğ·subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ·ğ‘ƒğœˆğ·\Upsilon(P)\coloneqq\lim_{|D|\to\infty}\mathbb{E}_{D\sim P}\nu(D)\ .roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) â‰” roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_D | â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D âˆ¼ italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) . (12)

Such definitions in Eq.Â 11 and Eq.Â 12 require a theoretically defined Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½ to understand and study the theoretical properties of the corresponding Î¥â¢(P)Î¥ğ‘ƒ\Upsilon(P)roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ), which is often not available, and also a characterization of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P due to the Dâˆ¼Psimilar-toğ·ğ‘ƒD\sim Pitalic_D âˆ¼ italic_P in the expectation, which is also not available.

To elaborate, the most commonly adopted choices of Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½, following [24], are defined through some empirical observations, e.g., the evaluation performance on a given validation set Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of a fixed ML model trained on Dğ·Ditalic_D. While for the purpose of implementation and experiments, for thusly defined Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½, Eq.Â 11 can be approximated reasonably well, there are difficulties when it comes to obtaining a theoretical analysis of Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥, primarily because the analytic expression of Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½ is difficult to obtain. This is because this analytic expression of Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½ depends on the choice of Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the ML model, the training procedure and etc. and can be complicated. An existing work proposes to utilize the framework of neural tangent kernel to help characterize Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½ [66], but nevertheless does not consider or define Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ or explicitly characterize the sampling distribution Pğ‘ƒPitalic_PÂ .

Secondly, Eq.Â 11 and Eq.Â 12 require a characterization of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P (because of ğ”¼Dâˆ¼Psubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ·ğ‘ƒ\mathbb{E}_{D\sim P}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D âˆ¼ italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), which has not been proposed or studied by prior works.

Therefore, instead of trying to extend the existing valuation methods defined for discrete datasets to data distributions, which would encounter the difficulties (of obtaining the analytic expression of Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½), we adopt the perspective of considering the distributions directly and propose a valuation for data distributions. The advantage of this perspective is that, a valuation defined for a distribution automatically yields a valuation for a dataset because the value of a distribution is essentially a population statistic while the corresponding value for the dataset is the sample statistic and is well defined. In other words, we propose the perspective of â€œgoing from data distributions to datasetsâ€, because of the appeal for theoretical analysis.

Q2.

What is the right interpretation of the problem statement and how it is connected to the theoretical results of 1 and TheoremÂ 1?

The problem statement asks for a prescriptive solution: A result that informs the buyer, in order to make the determination that Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P is more valuable than Pâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P^{\prime}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by some amount Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ (i.e., this is what the buyer wants), here is what the buyer needs to observe. This is made precise by 1 and TheoremÂ 1 where the amount Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ is denoted as ÎµÎ¥subscriptğœ€Î¥\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and what the buyer needs to observe is that Î½â¢(D)>Î½â¢(Dâ€²)+Î”Î¥,Î½.ğœˆğ·ğœˆsuperscriptğ·â€²subscriptÎ”Î¥ğœˆ\nu(D)>\nu(D^{\prime})+\Delta_{\Upsilon,\nu}\ .italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) > italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¥ , italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Suppose that the buyer observes that this inequality is not satisfied, then the buyer could decide not to make the decision, make the decision but with a lower confidence (i.e., larger Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´), or request that the vendors to provide a larger sample size, as elaborated in the paragraphs following 1 and TheoremÂ 1 respectively.

We note that our results, by design, differ from an inferential policy where a buyer, upon passively observing Î½â¢(D),Î½â¢(Dâ€²)ğœˆğ·ğœˆsuperscriptğ·â€²\nu(D),\nu(D^{\prime})italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) , italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and their difference Î½â¢(D)âˆ’Î½â¢(Dâ€²)ğœˆğ·ğœˆsuperscriptğ·â€²\nu(D)-\nu(D^{\prime})italic_Î½ ( italic_D ) - italic_Î½ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), tries to infer the difference Î¥â¢(P)âˆ’Î¥â¢(Pâ€²).Î¥ğ‘ƒÎ¥superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\Upsilon(P)-\Upsilon(P^{\prime})\ .roman_Î¥ ( italic_P ) - roman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

We believe that in our motivated settings (i.e., data marketplaces), a prescriptive policy is more useful, since the buyer can use it to make proactive decisions/actions (e.g., specifying how much more valuable Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P than Pâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P^{\prime}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to purchase Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P, requesting a larger sample from the vendor), instead of being a passive observer (such as in the inferential policy).

Q3.

Why is there a hypothetical column player?

Answer: The hypothetical column player is used to clearly represent the fact that the buyer (i.e., the row player) does not have prior knowledge about the vendors. Effectively, to the buyer, before having seen or bought the vendorsâ€™ distributions, all vendors are equivalent. Then, in this two-player game formulation, the column player (via its action space of all possible permutations) effective models this fact. The implication is that this finite, two-player zero-sum game can be analyzed without explicitly knowing the payoff matrix â„›â„›\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R to show that the uniform strategy is indeed worst-case optimal (3).

Q4.

Can some prior knowledge about the data vendors be used to design a better solution than PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT?

Answer: In principle, yes. However, it is yet unclear precisely what form of prior knowledge to consider, and then how to exploit it to design a better solution. One possibility to build on top of the two-player game formulation is to apply a prior belief over the rankings of the vendors in terms of the qualities of their distributions and then try to solve the corresponding game. It thus forms an interesting future direction to explore.

Q5.

Is the uniform mixture optimal?

Answer: The uniform strategy is worst-case optimal in the game defined as in Eq.Â 4, and it inspired our choice of the uniform mixture. A possible extension is to the infinite game version where the row player searches for some â€œoptimalâ€ Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ over â–³â¢(nâˆ’1)â–³ğ‘›1\triangle(n-1)â–³ ( italic_n - 1 ) (formalized via Eq.Â 8 and elaborated in App.Â A), but it is faced with additional difficulties, as detailed in the discussion following Eq.Â 8. It is not yet clear whether the uniform mixture would be (a part of) the optimal solution to the more complex infinite game, and thus presents an interesting exploration.

Q6.

Given the setting of no ground truth, and no prior knowledge about the data vendors, intuitively it does seem that one cannot do better than the uniform strategy. Then, is there some lower bound (of error) that matches the upper bound of error (e.g., 2 or CorollaryÂ 1)?

Answer: We provide an informal discussion based on two different perspectives (one from the field of robust statistics and the other from mechanism design).

Firstly, in the field of robust statistics, a lower bound of error for some estimation problem is often studied and there is indeed literature specifically studying the Huber model. But the differences in settings make their results not directly applicable, though instructive for us. For instance, [40] derive an information-theoretic lower bound of error for mean estimation using data sampled from a Huber model Pâ‰”(1âˆ’Îµ)â¢Pâˆ—+Îµâ¢Qâ‰”ğ‘ƒ1ğœ€superscriptğ‘ƒğœ€ğ‘„P\coloneqq(1-\varepsilon)P^{*}+\varepsilon Qitalic_P â‰” ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Îµ italic_Q where the lower bound is at least linear in Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ [40, Observation I.4], but does not have a result on the statistical difference between Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q. Nevertheless, this lower bound seems to already match our upper bound (e.g. 2) w.r.t.Â Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ (i.e., linear). Two key differences in the setting are: (i) we have multiple data vendors where [40] study only one, so we need to additionally consider how to â€œcombineâ€ these data vendors; (ii) the result in [40] is w.r.t.Â the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm, which is different from MMD (an RKHS norm) though there are similarities that can be used. We expand on how these differences make it difficult to directly apply the results of [20, 40], but also outline an informal sketch of how to adapt their results in Sec.Â B.3, which could be an interesting future direction.

Secondly, in the field of mechanism design where some interaction among multiple â€œagentsâ€ (i.e., data vendors in our setting) is typically present, a similar result (though in a different flavor from the error bound in robust statistics) is also observed. [36, 37, 44] point out that it is indeed impossible for a mechanism (e.g., a designed data valuation) to guarantee truthfulness if (i) there is no ground truth, and (ii) the data vendors are not assumed to be independent. Here truthfulness is related to the error of a valuation function where if the valuation function has 00 error (i.e., we manage to find some PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT s.t.Â PÏ‰=Pâˆ—subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒP_{\omega}=P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), truthfulness is guaranteed. By the contra-positive of this impossibility, without making further assumptions (the precise form of which is yet unclear), in our setting, it is impossible to design a valuation function that has an arbitrarily low error, or equivalently to find some PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with an arbitrarily small MMD to Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. While this result is not quantitative as the error lower bound from robust statistics, it is useful nevertheless because it applies to our setting with multiple data vendors, no prior knowledge about the data vendors and no ground truth.

We hope that our discussion here and our work can generate more interest in exploring these interesting directions (e.g., to obtain a matching lower bound of error), and that our described framework and proposed method can provide a theoretical basis for such future explorations.

Q7.

Instead of Eq.Â 4, why canâ€™t an optimization/search be performed directly over the convex mixture of Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s by assuming that âˆƒÏ‰âˆ—âˆˆâ–³â¢(nâˆ’1)superscriptğœ”â–³ğ‘›1\exists\omega^{*}\in\triangle(n-1)âˆƒ italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ â–³ ( italic_n - 1 ) s.t.Â PÏ‰â£âˆ—=Pâˆ—subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”superscriptğ‘ƒP_{\omega*}=P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT?

Answer: Suppose that âˆ€i,Îµiâ‰ 0,Qiâ‰ Pâˆ—formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘–subscriptğœ€ğ‘–0subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒ\forall i,\varepsilon_{i}\neq 0,Q_{i}\neq P^{*}âˆ€ italic_i , italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  0 , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then it can be shown that any convex mixture of Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s is not Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, because any convex mixture necessarily contains a (mixture) component that is not Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., ÎµÏ‰â¢QÏ‰subscriptğœ€ğœ”subscriptğ‘„ğœ”\varepsilon_{\omega}Q_{\omega}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in 1). Now, suppose it is relaxed that for some iâˆ—superscriptğ‘–i^{*}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Piâˆ—=Pâˆ—.subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒP_{i^{*}}=P^{*}\ .italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Then the main problem reduces to finding that iâˆ—superscriptğ‘–i^{*}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT out of nğ‘›nitalic_n vendors without having prior knowledge about the vendors, which indeed corresponds to the game described by Eq.Â 4. Similarly, the same game can be generalized to to finding argminidâ¢(Pâˆ—,Pi)subscriptargminğ‘–ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–\operatorname*{argmin}_{i}d(P^{*},P_{i})roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) even if miniâ¡dâ¢(pi,Pâˆ—)â‰ 0.subscriptğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒ0\min_{i}d(p_{i},P^{*})\neq 0\ .roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰  0 . Essentially, in both cases (either miniâ¡dâ¢(Pi,Pâˆ—)=0subscriptğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒ0\min_{i}d(P_{i},P^{*})=0roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 or miniâ¡dâ¢(Pi,Pâˆ—)â‰ 0subscriptğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒ0\min_{i}d(P_{i},P^{*})\neq 0roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰  0), the same described by Eq.Â 4 can be instantiated for which 3 is applicable.

Regarding the direct search over âˆƒÏ‰âˆ—âˆˆâ–³â¢(nâˆ’1)superscriptğœ”â–³ğ‘›1\exists\omega^{*}\in\triangle(n-1)âˆƒ italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ â–³ ( italic_n - 1 ), an additional discussion that suggests some additional assumptions (with yet unclear precise forms) may be necessary, is included in Sec.Â A.4.3.

Q8.

(How) can this method be applied if the sample datasets of the vendors have different sizes?

Answer: Yes: Suppose that the sample datasets Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s have different sizes, then it is possible to use the minimum size mminsubscriptğ‘šminm_{\text{min}}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of these sample datasets and uniformly randomly select a subset Di,subsubscriptğ·ğ‘–subD_{i,\text{sub}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , sub end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from each Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of size mminsubscriptğ‘šminm_{\text{min}}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT so that the resulting subsets Di,subsubscriptğ·ğ‘–subD_{i,\text{sub}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , sub end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s have equal sizes. This is mentioned as an implementation detail in Sec.Â 5 and hence in our experiments, w.l.o.g.Â we assume that the sample datasets have the same size.

Q9.

Is this method still effective if the Huber model is not satisfied?

Answer: While our theoretical results are specific to the Huber model (to exploit the analytic properties of MMD and Huber, e.g., in 2), some preliminary empirical results (in App.Â D) under two specific non-Huber settings do demonstrate that our method can remain effective even if the Huber model is not satisfied.

Q10.

What are the difficulties of extending the theoretical results beyond the Huber model?

Answer: There are two main difficulties: (1) how to provide a formal treatment of the interactions of multiple vendors? with the Huber model, 1 suggests that the convex mixture is one effective way. (2) how to analyze the effect of heterogeneity on the value of data? with the Huber model, Eq.Â 2 provides a simple yet intuitive way to do so.

Q11.

How is the extension â€œOurs cond.â€ different?

Answer: Our method (denoted as Ours) focuses on the features of the sample datasets and does not exploit the label information in these datasets. In contrast, some baselines such as (LAVA and CS) do exploit the label information. The extension (denoted as Ours cond.) is to demonstrate that our proposed MMD-based approach can be extended to also exploit the label information, if available. In essence, while â€œOursâ€ uses the MMD between the feature distributions, â€œOurs cond.â€ uses the MMD between the conditional distributions (i.e., distribution of label conditioned on feature). The implementation details are provided in Sec.Â 5 and App.Â D.

Q12.

What is the difference between Dtestsubscriptğ·testD_{\text{test}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT test end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT?

Answer: Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is included to accommodate some baselines that require it in order to enable a comparison. We highlight that it is an assumption that these baselines require in their works, and our method does not require Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In contrast, Dtestsubscriptğ·testD_{\text{test}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT test end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is used only for the purposes of evaluation so that we can compare different baselines (i.e., valuation methods). Dtestsubscriptğ·testD_{\text{test}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT test end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not required to implement our method.

Q13.

Why is there a need to use a common ground truth ğœ»ğœ»\boldsymbol{\zeta}bold_italic_Î¶ and what is the interpretation of it being the expected test performance?

Answer: The purpose of ğœ»ğœ»\boldsymbol{\zeta}bold_italic_Î¶ is for the evaluation and comparison of multiple methods as in Sec.Â 5. In practice, none of the methods can have a dependence on ğœ»ğœ»\boldsymbol{\zeta}bold_italic_Î¶.

For its purpose of evaluation and comparison, ğœ»ğœ»\boldsymbol{\zeta}bold_italic_Î¶ is meant to denote a sensible and interpretable value (i.e., ground truth) for the distributions. A sensible value refers to that the ground-truth value of Î¶isubscriptğœğ‘–\zeta_{i}italic_Î¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT should make sense. For instance, a data distribution Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with a high Îµisubscriptğœ€ğ‘–\varepsilon_{i}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a high dâ¢(Pâˆ—,Qi)ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–d(P^{*},Q_{i})italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) should not have a high ground-truth value Î¶isubscriptğœğ‘–\zeta_{i}italic_Î¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. An interpretable value requires ğœ»ğœ»\boldsymbol{\zeta}bold_italic_Î¶ to be simple and directly understandable since ğœ»ğœ»\boldsymbol{\zeta}bold_italic_Î¶ will be used as a reference, and if it is not interpretable, then it is difficult to draw analysis of the comparison obtained using ğœ»ğœ»\boldsymbol{\zeta}bold_italic_Î¶ as the reference.

As such, in our empirical investigation, we implement ğœ»ğœ»\boldsymbol{\zeta}bold_italic_Î¶ as the expected test performance which is interpretable since test performance directly informs the user how well the model trained on some data performs, and it is sensible as it is adopted by existing methods [25, 57, 70].

Appendix D Additional Experimental Settings and Results
