MNIST [41]: Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0. EMNIST [16]: CC0: Public Domain. FaMNIST [67]: The MIT License (MIT). CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 [38]: The MIT License (MIT). CaliH [35]: CC0: Public Domain. KingH [28]: CC0: Public Domain. TON [47]: CC0: Public Domain. UGR16 [45]: CC0: Public Domain. Credit7 [49]: CC0: Public Domain. Credit31 [3]: CC0: Public Domain. Census15, Census17 [48]: CC0: Public Domain.

Our experiments are run on a server with Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6226R CPU @2.902.902.902.90GHz and 4444 NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3080308030803080â€™s (each with 10101010Â GBs memory). We run our experiments for 5555 independent trials to report the average and standard errors.

D.2 Additional Experimental Settings

TableÂ 4 provides an overall summary of the experimental settings.

Additional dataset preprocessing details.

For CaliH and KingH, the pre-processing is passing the original (raw) data through a neural network (i.e., feature extractor) with the last layer having 10101010 units [1, 69]. Hence, the dimensionality after preprocessing is 10101010.

Credit7 has 7777 features while Credit31 has 31313131 features, so the top 7777 principal components are kept for Credit31. TON and UGR16 have the same feature space including features such as packet byte, source and destination IP addresses, but non-numerical features such as IP addresses are converted to one-hot encoding.

For TON and UGR16, which share the same feature space containing features such as source and destination IP addresses, packet size, network protocol and etc, we adopt the one-hot encoding for non-numerical features (i.e., source and destination IPs, network protocol) and perform standard scaling of the numerical features (i.e., packet size). The dimensionality after preprocessing is 22222222.

ML model ğŒğŒ\mathbf{M}bold_M specification details.

For MNIST vs.Â EMNIST and MNIST vs.Â FaMNIST, a standard 2-layer convoluntional neural network (CNN) is adopted. For CIFAR10 vs.Â CIFAR100, the ResNet-18 [29] is adopted. For both Credit7 vs.Â Credit31, and TON vs.Â UGR16, a standard logistic regression with the corresponding input sizes is adopted. The specific implementation (i.e., source code) is provided in the supplementary material for reference.

Additional implementation details on Ours cond.

Different from directly computing MMD between the features, this extension of our method aims to additionally utilize the label information contained within each Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Recall that each single data point in Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is paired feature-label, so this extension aims to exploit such information. Theoretically, MMD is well-defined w.r.t.Â distributions, be it distributions over only the features (i.e., PXsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‹P_{X}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) or conditional distributions of the labels given features (i.e., PY|Xsubscriptğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘Œğ‘‹P_{Y|X}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y | italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). For implementation, we need a representation for PY|Xsubscriptğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘Œğ‘‹P_{Y|X}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y | italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for a Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In our implementation, we train a machine learner ğŒiâ‰”ğŒâ¢(Di)â‰”subscriptğŒğ‘–ğŒsubscriptğ·ğ‘–\mathbf{M}_{i}\coloneqq\mathbf{M}(D_{i})bold_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” bold_M ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) on Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and use it to construct the empirical representation for PY|Xsubscriptğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘Œğ‘‹P_{Y|X}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y | italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Given a reference Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we collect the set of predictions (denoted as ğŒiâ¢(Dval)subscriptğŒğ‘–subscriptğ·val\mathbf{M}_{i}(D_{\text{val}})bold_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )) of ğŒisubscriptğŒğ‘–\mathbf{M}_{i}bold_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on this reference, as the empirical representation of PY|Xsubscriptğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘Œğ‘‹P_{Y|X}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y | italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Subsequently, we compute the data values, namely negated MMD between ğŒiâ¢(Dval)subscriptğŒğ‘–subscriptğ·val\mathbf{M}_{i}(D_{\text{val}})bold_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and, the labels of Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., the columns under Ïâ¢(ğ‚,ğœ»)ğœŒğ‚ğœ»\rho(\boldsymbol{\nu},\boldsymbol{\zeta})italic_Ï ( bold_italic_Î½ , bold_italic_Î¶ ) in TableÂ 2). Note that the predictions (i.e., ğŒiâ¢(Dval)subscriptğŒğ‘–subscriptğ·val\mathbf{M}_{i}(D_{\text{val}})bold_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )) are probability vectors in the Câˆ’1ğ¶1C-1italic_C - 1-probability simplex â–³â¢(Câˆ’1)â–³ğ¶1\triangle(C-1)â–³ ( italic_C - 1 ) for classification with Cğ¶Citalic_C classes, or real-values for regression. For MMD computation, a one-hot encoding of the labels in Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for classification is performed; no additional processing is required for the labels for regression.

Reproducibility statement.

We have included the necessary details to ensure the reproducibility of our theoretical and empirical results. Regarding theoretical results, the full set of assumptions, derivations and proofs for each theoretical result is clearly stated in either the main paper, or App.Â A. Regarding experiments: (i) the code to produce the experiments is included in a zip file as part of the supplementary material. It also contains the code and scripts to process the data used in the experiments. (ii) the processing steps and the licenses of the datasets used in the experiments, and the parameters (e.g., the choice of ML model used) that describe our experimental settings are clearly described in App.Â D. (iii) The information of the computational resources (i.e., hardware) used in our experiments and a set of scalability results for our method are included in App.Â D.

D.3 Additional Experimental Results

D.3.1 Additional Results for Empirical Convergence

Figs.Â 3, 4 andÂ 5 demonstrate that our method (i.e., MMD) performs overall the best (converges the most quickly) on TON, CIFAR10 and Credit7, respectively. Note that on these three datasets (i.e., CIFAR10, TON and Credit), the baseline LAVA did not complete due to a known runtime error (see Github issue) of a required package OTDD.

D.3.2 Experimental Verification of Correlation between True Values vs. Distribution Errors

This experiment serves as a preliminary verification on the empirical suitability of our proposed valuation in Eq.Â 1: Whether/how well do the measured values (i.e., Î½^^ğœˆ\hat{\nu}over^ start_ARG italic_Î½ end_ARG in Eq.Â 3) correlate with the error levels (i.e., dâ¢(P,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒd(P,P^{*})italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ))? The specific settings are as follows,

  1. 1.

    We consider discrete distributions for Pâˆ—,Pi,Qisuperscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–P^{*},P_{i},Q_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We randomly generate 1111-dimensional discrete (not necessarily uniform) distributions supported on the integers in [0,10]010[0,10][ 0 , 10 ]. We first generate Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, for each vendor iğ‘–iitalic_i, we randomly generate another distribution as Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and also an Îµiâˆ¼Uniformâ¢(0,0.5)similar-tosubscriptğœ€ğ‘–Uniform00.5\varepsilon_{i}\sim\text{Uniform}(0,0.5)italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ Uniform ( 0 , 0.5 ) (so that the outlier is not overpowering the ground truth) for Pi=(1âˆ’Îµi)â¢Pâˆ—+Îµiâ¢Qisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–1subscriptğœ€ğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ€ğ‘–subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–P_{i}=(1-\varepsilon_{i})P^{*}+\varepsilon_{i}Q_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    The error level of distribution is measured by d(Pi,Pâˆ—d(P_{i},P^{*}italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT).

  3. 3.

    The MMD is computed via the analytic expression in Eq.Â 6 in App.Â A, with a radial basis function kernel kâ¢(x,xâ€²;Ïƒ)=expâ¡(âˆ’â€–xâˆ’xâ€²â€–22â¢Ïƒ2)ğ‘˜ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğœsuperscriptnormğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²22superscriptğœ2k(x,x^{\prime};\sigma)=\exp(\frac{-\|x-x^{\prime}\|^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}})italic_k ( italic_x , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Ïƒ ) = roman_exp ( divide start_ARG - âˆ¥ italic_x - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) and Ïƒ=1ğœ1\sigma=1italic_Ïƒ = 1.

Note that the true value Î¥â¢(Pi)=âˆ’dâ¢(Pi,Pâˆ—)Î¥subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒ\Upsilon(P_{i})=-d(P_{i},P^{*})roman_Î¥ ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = - italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) by definition.

Correlation between obtained values and error levels.

In Fig.Â 6, the high r2superscriptğ‘Ÿ2r^{2}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT coefficient and pğ‘pitalic_p-value (of a fitted linear regression) indicate that the valuation scores correlate with and thus can reveal the error levels. Additionally, the more extensive results on up to n=1000ğ‘›1000n=1000italic_n = 1000 vendors in TableÂ 5 demonstrate a consistently high Pearson correlation coefficient between the true values (i.e., negated errors) and the measured/approximated values.

D.3.3 Additional Results for Huber Setting

We present the remaining results for the Huber setting for Credit7/Credit31, MNIST/EMNIST, and MNIST/FaMNIST in TablesÂ 6, 7 andÂ 8, respectively. Note that the results for Ïâ¢(ğ‚,ğœ»)ğœŒğ‚ğœ»\rho(\boldsymbol{\nu},\boldsymbol{\zeta})italic_Ï ( bold_italic_Î½ , bold_italic_Î¶ ) are obtained w.r.t.Â an available Dvalâˆ¼Pâˆ—similar-tosubscriptğ·valsuperscriptğ‘ƒD_{\text{val}}\sim P^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the reference. Hence, our method directly uses Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (since it is equivalent to Dâˆ—superscriptğ·D^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by definition) in Eq.Â 1 when Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is available. Our method uses DÏ‰subscriptğ·ğœ”D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., Eq.Â 3) when Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is unavailable (i.e., the right columns). We highlight that Ours cond. is not applicable for when Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is unavailable because the conditional distribution required is not well-defined when the reference (i.e., DÏ‰subscriptğ·ğœ”D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) is from a Huber distribution.

D.3.4 Results for Non-Huber Setting

We investigate two non-Huber settings: (1) additive Gaussian noise; (2) different supports [68], which is also generalized to an interpolated setting where the interpolation is between the different supports.

Setting. (1) Additive Gaussian noise: Among n=10ğ‘›10n=10italic_n = 10 vendors, the dataset Diâˆ¼Piâ‰”MNIST+ğ’©â¢(ğŸ,ÎµiÃ—ğˆ)similar-tosubscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–â‰”MNISTğ’©0subscriptğœ€ğ‘–ğˆD_{i}\sim P_{i}\coloneqq\text{MNIST}+\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0},\varepsilon_{i}% \times\mathbf{I})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” MNIST + caligraphic_N ( bold_0 , italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— bold_I ) where |Di|=mi=5000subscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘–5000|D_{i}|=m_{i}=5000| italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 5000 and the Îµisubscriptğœ€ğ‘–\varepsilon_{i}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s are [0,0.02,â€¦,0.18]00.02â€¦0.18[0,0.02,\ldots,0.18][ 0 , 0.02 , â€¦ , 0.18 ]. Note that though Pâˆ—=MNISTsuperscriptğ‘ƒMNISTP^{*}=\text{MNIST}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = MNIST, each Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not Huber. (2) The supports of Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that each vendor can sample from are different: on MNIST, vendor 1111 only collects images of digits 00, while vendor 10101010 collects images of all 10101010 digits (called classimbalance [68]). Intuitively, vendor 10101010 has access to Pâˆ—superscriptğ‘ƒP^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT so its data should be the most valuable. Results. TablesÂ 9 andÂ 10 show that, when Dvalâˆ¼Pâˆ—similar-tosubscriptğ·valsuperscriptğ‘ƒD_{\text{val}}\sim P^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is available, the methods (i.e., DAVINZ, CS) that can effectively utilize Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can outperform our method. However, without Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, these methods still underperform our method, especially under additive Gaussian noise. We believe it could be because these methods were not specifically designed to account for heterogeneity (which could be caused by noise), since CS performs comparably well under the class imbalance setting where the heterogeneity is due to the supports of the vendors being different instead of random noise. In particular, we find that all baselines perform sub-optimally under the additive Gaussian noise setting and when there is no clean Dvalsubscriptğ·valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT available, which can be an interesting future direction. A possible reason is that the Gaussian noise is completely uncorrelated to the features and â€œdestroysâ€ the information in the data, rendering the valuation methods ineffective.

Interpolated classimbalance setting. In addition to the â€œdiscreteâ€ class imbalance setting, we also investigate an interpolated setting as follows: For MNIST, n=5,mi=5000formulae-sequenceğ‘›5subscriptğ‘šğ‘–5000n=5,m_{i}=5000italic_n = 5 , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 5000, half of Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT consists of images of first 2â¢i+12ğ‘–12i+12 italic_i + 1 digits while the other half consists of images of all 10101010 digits. E.g., 2500250025002500 of D3subscriptğ·3D_{3}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are images of digits of 0âˆ’6060-60 - 6 while the other 2500250025002500 are images of digits of 0âˆ’9090-90 - 9. Effectively, each Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains images of all 10101010 digits, but in different proportions which increase as iğ‘–iitalic_i increases from 1111 to 5555. For CIFAR-10, n=5,mi=10000formulae-sequenceğ‘›5subscriptğ‘šğ‘–10000n=5,m_{i}=10000italic_n = 5 , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10000 with the same interpolation implementation. Results are in TableÂ 11. Note that for the non-Huber setting here, since the heterogeneity is only in the supports of the data (i.e., features) and not the labels, the conditional distribution for Ours cond. is indeed well-defined and thus Ours cond. is applicable here. This is different from the Huber setting examined in Sec.Â 5.

D.3.5 Preliminary Experimental Results on Incentive Compatibility

We empirically demonstrate that mis-reporting decreases a vendorâ€™s value, suggesting that IC can be satisfied (approximately), as hypothesized in Sec.Â A.4.3.

Settings. Vendor iâ€²âˆˆNsuperscriptğ‘–â€²ğ‘i^{\prime}\in Nitalic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_N is designated to mis-report: D~iâ€²â†Diâ€²+ğ’©â¢(0,ğ•€â¢Ïƒ2)â†subscript~ğ·superscriptğ‘–â€²subscriptğ·superscriptğ‘–â€²ğ’©0ğ•€superscriptğœ2\tilde{D}_{i^{\prime}}\leftarrow D_{i^{\prime}}+\mathcal{N}(0,\mathbb{I}\sigma% ^{2})over~ start_ARG italic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â† italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + caligraphic_N ( 0 , blackboard_I italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for Ïƒ2=0.2superscriptğœ20.2\sigma^{2}=0.2italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.2, namely, vendor iâ€²superscriptğ‘–â€²i^{\prime}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT adds zero-mean Gaussian noise to the features of the data in Diâ€²subscriptğ·superscriptğ‘–â€²D_{i^{\prime}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This ensures dâ¢(P~iâ€²,Pâˆ—)>dâ¢(Piâ€²,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘subscript~ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘–â€²superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘–â€²superscriptğ‘ƒd(\tilde{P}_{i^{\prime}},P^{*})>d(P_{i^{\prime}},P^{*})italic_d ( over~ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) > italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). For evaluation, we compute the data values (i) using Eq.Â 1 with a test set Dâˆ—âˆ¼Pâˆ—similar-tosuperscriptğ·superscriptğ‘ƒD^{*}\sim P^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the reference, denoted as the ground truth (GT); (ii) using Eq.Â 3 (i.e., Ours) and Tay etÂ al. [59, Eq.Â (1)] (i.e., MMD2), respectively, with DÏ‰subscriptğ·ğœ”D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the reference. We include MMD2 to investigate how the square affects IC (since IC of Ours can leverage the the triangle inequality of MMD that is not satisfied by MMD2).

Corresponding to the ideal case discussed in Sec.Â A.4.3, using Dâˆ—superscriptğ·D^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can achieve an approximate-IC with a desirable Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. In other words, GT is likely to correctly reflect the values of the vendors (including the mis-reporting iâ€²superscriptğ‘–â€²i^{\prime}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). Hence, for Ours and MMD2, if the data values are consistent with GT, that it suggests that (approximate) IC is more likely to be achieved.

Results. Fig.Â 7 (resp.Â Fig.Â 8) plots the average and standard error over 5555 independent trials of the change in data values of the n=5ğ‘›5n=5italic_n = 5 (resp.Â n=10ğ‘›10n=10italic_n = 10) vendors as we sweep the identity of the mis-reporting vendor iâ€²âˆˆ{2,3,4}superscriptğ‘–â€²234i^{\prime}\in\{2,3,4\}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ { 2 , 3 , 4 }.777The standard error bars are not visible because of the low variation across independent trials. Specifically, the change in data value (i.e., yğ‘¦yitalic_y-axis) is defined as the difference between the value of iğ‘–iitalic_i when some iâ€²superscriptğ‘–â€²i^{\prime}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (possibly iâ€²=isuperscriptğ‘–â€²ğ‘–i^{\prime}=iitalic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_i) is mis-reporting, and that of iğ‘–iitalic_i for when no vendor is mis-reporting. IC implies a negative change (i.e., decrease) in value for the mis-reporting iâ€²superscriptğ‘–â€²i^{\prime}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is observed for GT, Ours, and MMD2 in both Figs.Â 7 andÂ 8.

Note that the magnitude of the decrease for mis-reporting vendor iâ€²superscriptğ‘–â€²i^{\prime}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT under Ours is more significant than that under MMD2; hence it may be easier to identify the mis-reporting vendor from the truthful ones. This happens because the MMD is bounded by 1111 (due to the choice of RBF kernel), and the square operation makes the value for MMD2 strictly smaller in magnitude than that for MMD (i.e., Ours), as âˆ€xâˆˆ(0,1),x2<xformulae-sequencefor-allğ‘¥01superscriptğ‘¥2ğ‘¥\forall x\in(0,1),x^{2}<x\ âˆ€ italic_x âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < italic_x. Therefore, MMD may be empirically more appealing than MMD2.

Additional results for investigating incentive compatibility under varying settings of P,Qğ‘ƒğ‘„P,Qitalic_P , italic_Q and nğ‘›nitalic_n are presented, in Figs.Â 9 andÂ 10 and TablesÂ 12, 14, 13 andÂ 15.

Figs.Â 9 andÂ 10 verify the observation that the mis-reporting vendor iâ€²superscriptğ‘–â€²i^{\prime}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a negative change (i.e., decrease) in value. Moreover, the magnitude of the decrease in value is more significant for Ours than that for MMD2. The additional set of quantitative result (i.e., the Pearson correlation coefficient between the GT data values and Ours or MMD2) also confirms this observation. To elaborate, take the value corresponding to iâ€²=2superscriptğ‘–â€²2i^{\prime}=2italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2 and MMD2 in TableÂ 12 as an example. The Pearson coefficient (i.e., 0.9990.9990.9990.999) is between the GT data values (i.e., a vector of length n=5ğ‘›5n=5italic_n = 5) and the MMD2 data values (i.e., a vector of length n=5ğ‘›5n=5italic_n = 5), under the setting that iâ€²=2superscriptğ‘–â€²2i^{\prime}=2italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2 is mis-reporting. The results in TablesÂ 12, 14, 13 andÂ 15 show that the data values of both Ours and MMD2 are very consistent with the GT values, importantly without having Dâˆ—âˆ¼Pâˆ—similar-tosuperscriptğ·superscriptğ‘ƒD^{*}\sim P^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the reference, thus suggesting that (approximate) IC is achievable. However, a caveat is that both methods are not very effective in achieving IC when iâ€²=1superscriptğ‘–â€²1i^{\prime}=1italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1. This is precisely because DÏ‰âˆ¼PÏ‰similar-tosubscriptğ·ğœ”subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”D_{\omega}\sim P_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is used as the reference in place of Dâˆ—âˆ¼Pâˆ—similar-tosuperscriptğ·superscriptğ‘ƒD^{*}\sim P^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as for GT, and expected (since the discussion in Sec.Â A.4.3 suggests that the a worse approximate-IC for PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Specifically, IC is empirically observed when dâ¢(Pâˆ’i,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒd(P_{-i},P^{*})italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is small. When iâ€²=1superscriptğ‘–â€²1i^{\prime}=1italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1, this is not satisfied, in other words dâ¢(Pâˆ’i,Pâˆ—)ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–superscriptğ‘ƒd(P_{-i},P^{*})italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) would be large. This is because, iâ€²=1superscriptğ‘–â€²1i^{\prime}=1italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 is the â€œbestâ€ vendor in our experiment settings in that Piâ€²=1=Pâˆ—subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘–â€²1superscriptğ‘ƒP_{i^{\prime}=1}=P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., Îµiâ€²=1=0subscriptğœ€superscriptğ‘–â€²10\varepsilon_{i^{\prime}=1}=0italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0). Hence, if iâ€²=1superscriptğ‘–â€²1i^{\prime}=1italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 mis-reports, the remaining vendors in Nâˆ–{iâ€²}ğ‘superscriptğ‘–â€²N\setminus\{i^{\prime}\}italic_N âˆ– { italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } are unable to catch iâ€²=1superscriptğ‘–â€²1i^{\prime}=1italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 because the aggregate distribution Pâˆ’iâ€²=Pâˆ’1subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘–â€²subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{-i^{\prime}}=P_{-1}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not a very good reference (as compared to Pâˆ’iâ€²subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘–â€²P_{-i^{\prime}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for iâ€²â‰ 1superscriptğ‘–â€²1i^{\prime}\neq 1italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  1 is mis-reporting). Intuitively, if i=1ğ‘–1i=1italic_i = 1 is not mis-reporting (i.e., iâ€²â‰ 1superscriptğ‘–â€²1i^{\prime}\neq 1italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  1), then Pâˆ’iâ€²subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘–â€²P_{-i^{\prime}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains the data from P1=Pâˆ—subscriptğ‘ƒ1superscriptğ‘ƒP_{1}=P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and is thus a good reference.

Overall, these empirical results suggest a promising future direction of achieving (approximate) IC, by choosing a suitable metric (e.g., MMD) against a carefully constructed reference (e.g., PUsubscriptğ‘ƒUP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

D.4 Observed Linear Scaling w.r.t.Â nğ‘›nitalic_n and mğ‘šmitalic_m

We demonstrate the scalability of our method w.r.t.Â the number nğ‘›nitalic_n of vendors and the sample size mğ‘šmitalic_m, in terms of execution time and memory (RAM and GPU).

Plots showing linear scaling.

Fig.Â 11 observes linear scaling between time vs.Â misubscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (top left), time vs.Â nğ‘›nitalic_n (bottom left), RAM vs.Â misubscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (top right) and RAM vs.Â nğ‘›nitalic_n (bottom right). Crucially, this helps ensure the practical applicability of our method in terms of implementation and execution.

RAM, CUDA and CPU time results.

We include the detailed results for RAM, CUDA, and time on MNIST (TablesÂ 20, 19 andÂ 21) and CIFAR10 (TablesÂ 17, 16 andÂ 18), respectively.

Scalability comparison against DAVINZ.

The implementation of DAVINZ also includes an MMD computation (similar to our proposed method), but additionally linearly combined with a the neural tangent kernel (NTK)-based score. While in some cases (e.g., TableÂ 3), DAVINZ and our proposed method perform comparably, we highlight that our method is more scalable. The main reason is that the gradient computation from NTK in DAVINZ requires additional memory, specifically CUDA memory due to leveraging GPU for gradient computation. See TableÂ 22 for a scalability experiment for DAVINZ with n=10ğ‘›10n=10italic_n = 10 on MNIST with a standard convolutional neural network used for all MNIST-related experiments in this work.

In contrast, under the same setting of n=10ğ‘›10n=10italic_n = 10 data vendors each with mi=10000subscriptğ‘šğ‘–10000m_{i}=10000italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10000 samples, our method requires less than 0.10.10.10.1 GBs of CUDA memory (see the fifth row, first column of TableÂ 19. Note that we were not able to collect results for DAVINZ on more extensive settings due to hardware limitations (i.e., larger values for nğ‘›nitalic_n and misubscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT leads to out-of-memory errors on our standard GPUs with 10101010 GBs of memory and the official implementation [66, Github repo] does not implement a way to take advantage of multiple GPUs (if available) to distribute the CUDA memory load.
